play.title:
AN
EXCELLENT
conceited Tragedie
OF
Romeo and Iuliet,

speech.speaker: Chorus

line.emph: VVo houſhold Frends alike in dignitie,

speech.line: (In faire Verona, where we lay our Scene)

line.emph: From ciuill broyles broke into enmitie,
VVhoſe ciuill warre makes ciuill hands vncleane.
From forth the fatall loynes of theſe two foes,
A paire of ﬅarre-croﬆ Louers tooke their life:
VVhoſe miſaduentures, piteous ouerthrowes,
(Through the continuing of their Fathers ﬅtrife,
And death-markt paﬀage of their Parents rage)
Is now the two howres traffique of our Stage.
The which if you with patient eares attend,
VVhat here we want wee’l ﬅudie to amend.

scene.scenetitle:
The moﬆ excellent Tragedie of
Romeo and Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Sampson
speech.line: GRegorie, of my word Ile carrie no coales.
No, for if you doo, you ſhould be a Collier.
If I be in choler, Ile draw.
Euer while you liue, drawe your necke out of the the collar.
I ﬅrike quickly being moou’d.
I, but you are not quickly moou’d to ﬅrike.
A Dog of the houſe of the Mountagues moues me.
To mooue is to ﬅirre, and to bee valiant is to ﬅand to it: therefore (of my word) if thou be mooud thou’t runne away.
There’s not a man of them I meete, but Ile take the wall of.
That ſhewes thee a weakling, for the weakeﬅ goes to the wall.
Thats true, therefore Ile thruﬅ the men from the wall, and thruﬅ the maids to the walls: nay, thou ſhalt ſee I am a tall peece of fleſh.
Tis well thou art not fiſh, for if thou wert thou wouldﬅ be but poore Iohn.
Ile play the tyrant, Ile firﬅ begin with the maids, & off with their heads.
The heads of the maids?
I the heades of their Maides, or the Maidenheades, take it in what ſence thou wilt.
Nay let them take it in ſence that ſeele it, but heere comes two of the Mountagues.

scene.stagedir: Enter two Seruingmen of the Mountagues.

speech.line: Nay feare not me I warrant thee.
I feare them no more than thee, but draw.
Nay let vs haue the law on our ﬁde, let them begin firﬅ. Ile tell thee what Ile doo, as I goe by ile bite my thumbe, which is diſgrace enough if they ſuffer it.
Content, goe thou by and bite thy thumbe, and ile come after and frowne.

speech.speaker: 1 Moun:
speech.line: Doo you bite your thumbe at vs?
I bite my thumbe.

speech.speaker: 2 Moun:
speech.line: I but i’ﬅ at vs?
I bite my thumbe, is the law on our ﬁde?
No.
I bite my thumbe.

speech.speaker: 1 Moun:
speech.line: I but i’ﬅ at vs?
Say I, here comes my Maﬅers kinſman.

scene.stagedir: They draw, to them enters Tybalt, they fight, to them the Prince, old Mountague, and his wife, old Capulet and his wife, and other Citizens and part them.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Rebellious ſubieƈts enemies to peace,
On paine of torture, from thoſe bloody handes
Throw your miﬅempered weapons to the ground.
Three Ciuell brawles bred of an airie word,
By the old Capulet and Mountague,
Haue thrice diﬅurbed the quiet of our ﬅreets.
If euer you diﬅurbe our ﬅreets againe,
Your liues ſhall pay the ranſome of your fault:
For this time euery man depart in peace.
Come Capulet come you along with me,
And Mountague, come you this after noone,
To know our farther pleaſure in this caſe,
To old free Towne our common iudgement place,
Once more on paine of death each man depart.

speech.speaker: M:
speech.line: wife, Who ſet this auncient quarrel firﬅ abroach?
Speake Nephew, were you by when it began?

speech.speaker: Benuo:
speech.line: Here were the ſeruants of your aduerſaries,
And yours cloſe fighting ere I did approch.

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: Ah where is Romeo, ſaw you him to day?
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Madame, an houre before the worſhipt ſunne
Peept through the golden window of the Eaﬅ,
A troubled thought drew me from companie:
Where vnderneath the groue Sicamoure,
That Weﬅward rooteth from the Citties ﬁde,
So early walking might I ſee your ſonne.
I drew towards him, but he was ware of me,
And drew into the thicket of the wood:
I noting his affeƈtions by mine owne,
That moﬅ are buﬁed when th’are moﬅ alone,
Perſued my honor, not purſuing his.

speech.speaker: Moun:
speech.line: Black and portentious muﬅ this honor proue,
Vnleﬀe good counſaile doo the cauſe remooue.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Why tell me Vncle do you know the cauſe?

speech.speaker: Moun:
speech.line: I neyther know it nor can learne of him.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: See where he is, but ﬅand you both aﬁde
Ile know his grieuance, or be much denied.

speech.speaker: Mount:
speech.line: I would thou wert ſo happie by thy ﬅay
To heare true ſhrift. Come Madame lets away.

speech.speaker: Benuo:
speech.line: Good morrow Coſen.

speech.speaker: Romeo:
speech.line: Is the day ſo young?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: But new ﬅroke nine.

speech.speaker: Romeo:
speech.line: Ay me, ſad hopes ſeeme long.
Was that my Father that went hence ſo faﬅ?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: It was, what ſorrow lengthens Romeos houres?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Not hauing that, which hauing makes them ſhort.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: In loue.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Out.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Of loue.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Out of her fauour where I am in loue.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Alas that loue ſo gentle in her view,
Should be ſo tyrranous and rough in proofe.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Alas that loue whoſe view is muffled ﬅill,
Should without lawes giue path-waies to our will:
Where ſhall we dine? Gods me, what fray was here?
Yet tell me not for I haue heard it all,
Heres much to doe with hate, but more with loue.
Why then, O brawling loue, O louing hate,
O anie thing, of nothing firﬅ create!
O heauie lightnes ſerious vanitie!
Miſhapen Caos of beﬅ ſeeming thinges,
Feather of lead, bright ſmoke, cold fire, ﬁcke health,
Still waking ﬂeepe, that is not what it is:
This loue feele I, which feele no loue in this.
Doeﬅ thou not laugh?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: No Coſe I rather weepe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Good hart at what?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: At thy good hearts oppreſsion.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Why ſuch is loues tranſgreſsion,
Griefes of mine owne lie heauie at my hart,
Which thou wouldﬅ propagate to haue them preﬅ
With more of thine, this griefe that thou haﬅ ſhowne,
Doth ad more griefe to too much of mine owne:
Loue is a ſmoke raiſde with the fume of ﬁghes
Being purgde, a fire ſparkling in louers eyes:
Being vext, a ſea raging with a louers teares.
What is it elſe? A madnes moﬅ diſcreet,
A choking gall, and a preſeruing ſweet. Farewell Coſe.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Nay Ile goe along.
And if you hinder me you doo me wrong.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Tut I haue loﬅ my ſelfe I am not here,
This is not Romeo, hee’s ſome other where.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Tell me in ſadnes whome ſhe is you loue?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: What ſhall I grone and tell thee?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Why no, but ſadly tell me who.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Bid a ﬁckman in ſadnes make his will.
Ah word ill vrgde to one that is ſo ill.
In ſadnes Coſen I doo loue a woman.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: I aimde ſo right, when as you ſaid you lou’d.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: A right good mark-man, and ſhee’s faire I loue.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: A right faire marke faire Coſe is ſooneﬅ hit.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: But in that hit you miﬀe, ſhee’le not be hit
With Cupids arrow, ſhe hath Dianaes wit,
And in ﬅrong proofe of chaﬅitie well arm’d:
Gainﬅ Cupids childiſh bow the liues vnharm’d,
Shee’le not abide the ﬁedge of louing tearmes,
Nor ope her lap to Saint ſeducing gold,
Ah ſhe is rich in beautie, only poore,
That when ſhe dies with beautie dies her ﬅore.
Of honorable reckoning are they both,
And pittie tis they liue at ods ſo long:
But leauing that, what ſay you to my ſute?

speech.speaker: Capu:
speech.line: What ſhould I ſay more than I ſaid before,
My daughter is a ﬅranger in the world,
Shee hath not yet attainde to fourteene yeares:
Let two more ſommers wither in their pride,
Before ſhe can be thought fit for a Bride.

speech.speaker: Paris:
speech.line: Younger than ſhe are happie mothers made.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: But too ſoone marde are theſe ſo early maried:
But wooe her gentle Paris, get her heart,
My word to her conſent is but a part.
This night I hold an old accuﬅom’d Feaﬅ,
Whereto I haue inuited many a gueﬅ,
Such as I loue: yet you among the ﬅore,
One more moﬅ welcome makes the number more.
At my poore houſe you ſhall behold this night,
Earth treadding ﬅars, that make darke heauen light:
Such comfort as doo luﬅy youngmen feele,
When well apparaild Aprill on the heele
Of lumping winter treads, euen ſuch delights
Amongﬅ freſh female buds ſhall you this night
Inherit at my houſe, heare all, all ſee,
And like her moﬅ, whoſe merite moﬅ ſhalbe.
Such amongﬅ view of many myne beeing one,
May ﬅand in number though in reckoning none.
Where are you ﬁrra, goe trudge about
Through faire Verona ﬅreets, and ſeeke them out:
Whoſe names are written here and to them ſay,
My houſe and welcome at their pleaſure ﬅay.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Seeke them out whoſe names are written here, and yet I knowe not who are written here: I muﬅ to the learned to learne of them, that’s as much to ſay, as the Taylor muﬅ meddle with his Laﬅe, the Shoomaker with his needle, the Painter with his nets, and the Fiſher with his Penﬁll, I muﬅ to the learned.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Tut man one fire burnes out anothers burning,
One paine is leﬀned with anothers anguiſh:
Turne backward, and be holp with backward turning,
One deſperate griefe cures with anothers languiſ.
Take thou ſome new infeƈtion to thy eye,
And the ranke poyſon of the old will die.

speech.speaker: Romeo:
speech.line: Your Planton leafe is excellent for that.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: For what?

speech.speaker: Romeo:
speech.line: For your broken ſhin.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Why Romeo art thou mad?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Not mad, but bound more then a mad man is.
Shut vp in priſon, kept without my foode,
Whipt and tormented, and Godden good fellow.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Godgigoden, I pray ﬁr can you read?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I mine owne fortune in my miſerie.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Perhaps you haue learned it without booke: but I pray can you read any thing you ſee?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I if I know the letters and the language.

speech.speaker: Seru:
speech.line: Yee ſay honeﬅly, reﬅ you merrie.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Stay fellow I can read.

SEigneur Martino and his wife and daughters, Countie Anſelme and his beauteous ﬁﬅers, the Ladie widdow of Vtruuio, Seigneur Placentio, and his louelie Neeces, Mercutio and his brother Valentine, mine vncle Capulet his wife and daughters, my faire Neece Roſaline and Liuia, Seigneur Valentio and his Coſen Tibalt, Lucio and the liuelie Hellena.
A faire aﬁembly, whether ſhould they come?

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Vp.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Whether to ſupper?

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: To our houſe.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Whoſe houſe?

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: My Maﬅers.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Indeed I ſhould haue askt thee that before.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Now Il’e tel you without asking. My Maﬅer is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the houſe of Mountagues, I pray come and cruſh a cup of wine. Reﬅ you merrie.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: At this ſame auncient feaﬅ of Capulets,
Sups the faire Roſaline whom thou ſo loues:
With all the admired beauties of Verona,
Goe thither and with vnattainted eye,
Compare her face with ſome that I ſhall ſhew,
And I will make thee thinke thy ſwan a crow.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: When the deuout religion of mine eye
Maintaines ſuch falſhood, then turne teares to fire,
And theſe who often drownde could neuer die,
Tranſparent Heretiques be burnt for liers.
One fairer than my loue, the all ſeeing ſonne
Nere ſaw her match, ﬁnce firﬅ the world begun.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Tut you ſaw her faire none els being by.
Her ſelfe poyld with her ſelfe in either eye:
But in that Criﬅall ſcales let there be waide,
Your Ladyes loue, againﬅ ſome other maide
That I will ſhew you ſhining at this feaﬅ,
And ſhe ſhall ſcant ſhew well that now ſeemes beﬅ.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Ile goe along no ſuch ﬁght to be ſhowne,
But to reioyce in ſplendor of mine owne.

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: Nurce wher’s my daughter call her forth to mee.

line.emph: Now by my maiden head at twelue yeare old I bad her come, what Lamb, what Ladie bird, God forbid.
VVher’s this girle? what Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Iuliet:
speech.line: How now who cals?

line.emph: Your Mother.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Madame I am here, what is your will?

speech.speaker: VV:
speech.line: This is the matter. Nurſe giue leaue a while, we muﬅ talke in ſecret. Nurce come back again I haue remembred me, thou’ſe heare our counſaile. Thou knoweﬅ my daughters of a prettie age.

line.emph: Faith I can tell her age vnto a houre.

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: Shee’s not fourteene.

speech.speaker: Nurce:

line.emph: Ile lay fourteene of my teeth, and yet to my teene be it ſpoken, I haue but foure, ſhee’s not fourteene.

speech.line: How long is it now to Lammas-tide?

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: A fortnight and odde dayes.

speech.speaker: Nurce:
speech.line: Euen or odde, of all dayes in the yeare come Lammas Eue at night ſhall ſhe be fourteene. Suſan and ſhe God reﬅ all Chriﬅian ſoules were of an age. VVell Suſan is with God, ſhe was too good for me: But as I ſaid on Lammas Eue at night ſhall ſhe be fourteene, that ſhall ſhee marie I remember it well. Tis ﬁnce the Earth-quake nowe eleauen yeares, and ſhe was weand I neuer ſhall forget it, of all the daies of the yeare vpon that day: for I had then laid wormewood to my dug, ﬁtting in the ſun vnder the Doue-houſe wall. My Lord and you were then at Mantua, nay I do beare a braine: But as I ſaid, when it did taﬅ the wormwood on the nipple of my dug, & felt it bitter, pretty foole to ſee it reachie and fall out with Dugge. Shake quoth the Doue-houſe twas no need I trow to bid me trudge, and ﬁnce that time it is a leauen yeare: for then could Iuliet ﬅande high lone, nay by the Roode, ſhee could haue wadled vp and downe, for euen the day before ſhee brake her brow, and then my husband God be with his ſoule, hee was a merrie man: Doﬅ thou fall forward Iuliet? thou wilt fall backward when thou haﬅ more wit: wilt thou not Iuliet? and by my hollidam, the pretty foole left crying and ſaid I. To ſee how a ieaﬅ ſhall come about, I warrant you if I ſhould liue a hundred yeare, I neuer ſhould forget it, wilt thou not Iuliet? and by my troth ſhe ﬅinted and cried I.

speech.speaker: Iuliet:
speech.line: And ﬅint thou too, I prethee Nurce ſay I.

line.emph: VVell goe thy waies, God marke thee for his grace, thou wert the prettieﬅ Babe that euer I nurﬅ, might I but liue to ſee thee married once, I haue my wiſh.

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: And that ſame marriage Nurce, is the Theame I meant to talke of: Tell me Iuliet, howe ﬅand you affeƈted to be married?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: It is an honor that I dreame not off.

line.emph: An honor! were not I thy onely Nurce, I would ſay thou hadﬅ ſuckt wiſedome from thy Teat.

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: Well girle, the Noble Countie Paris ſeekes thee for his Wife.

line.emph: A man young Ladie, Ladie ſuch a man as all the world, why he is a man of waxe.

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: Veronaes Summer hath not ſuch a flower.

line.emph: Nay he is a flower, in faith a very flower.

speech.speaker: VVife:
speech.line: Well Iuliet, how like you of Paris loue.

speech.speaker: Iuliet:
speech.line: Ile looke to like, if looking liking moue,
But no more deepe will I engage mine eye,
Then your conſent giues ﬅrength to make it flie.

line.emph: Maddam you are cald for, ſupper is readie, the Nurce curﬅ in the Pantrie, all thinges in extreamitie, make haﬅ for I muﬅ be gone to waite.

scene.stagedir: Enter Maskers with Romeo and a Page.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: What ſhall this ſpeech beeſpoke for our excuſe?
Or ſhall we on without Apologie.

speech.speaker: Benuoleo:
speech.line: The date is out of ſuch prolixitie,
Weele haue no Cupid hudwinckt with a Scarfe,
Bearing a Tartars painted bow of lath,
Scaring the Ladies like a crow-keeper:
Nor no without booke Prologue faintly ſpoke
After the Prompter, for our entrance.
But let them meaſure vs by what they will,
Weele meaſure them a meaſure and be gone.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: A torch for me I am not for this aumbling,
Beeing but heauie I will beare the light.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Beleeue me Romeo I muﬅ haue you daunce.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Not I beleeue me you haue dancing ſhooes
With nimble ſoles, I haue a ſoule of lead
So ﬅakes me to the ground I cannot ﬅirre.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Giue me a caſe to put my viſage in,
A viſor for a viſor, what care I
What curious eye doth coate deformitie.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Giue me a Torch, let wantons light of hart
Tickle the ſenceles ruſhes with their heeles:
For I am prouerbd with a Grandﬁre phraſe,
Ile be a candleholder and looke on,
The game was nere ſo faire and I am done.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Tut dun’s the mouſe the Cunﬅables old word,
If thou beeﬅ Dun, weele draw thee from the mire
Of this ſurreuerence loue wherein thou ﬅickﬅ.
Leaue this talke, we burne day light here.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Nay thats not ſo.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: I meane ﬁr in delay,
We burne our lights by night, like Lampes by day,
Take our good meaning for our iudgement ﬁts
Three times a day, ere once in her right wits.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: So we meane well by going to this maske:
But tis no wit to goe.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Why Romeo may one aske?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I dreamt a dreame to night.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: And ſo did I.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Why what was yours?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: That dreamers often lie.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: In bed a ﬂeepe while they doe dreame things true.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Ah then I ſee Queene Mab hath bin with you.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Queene Mab whats ſhe?
She is the Fairies Midwife and doth come
In ſhape no bigger than an Aggat ﬅone
On the forefinger of a Burgomaﬅer,
Drawne with a teeme of little Atomi,
A thwart mens noſes when they lie a ﬂeepe.
Her waggon ſpokes are made of ſpinners webs,
The couer, of the winges of Graſhoppers,
The traces are the Moone-ſhine watrie beames,
The collers crickets bones, the laſh of filmes,
Her waggoner is a ſmall gray coated flie,
Not halfe ſo big as is a little worme,
Pickt from the laﬁe finger of a maide,
And in this ſort ſhe gallops vp and downe
Through Louers braines, and then they dream of loue:
O’re Courtiers knees: who ﬅrait on curﬁes dreame
O’re Ladies lips, who dreame on kiﬀes ﬅrait:
Which oft the angrie Mab with bliﬅers plagues,
Becauſe their breathes with ſweet meats tainted are:
Sometimes ſhe gallops ore a Lawers lap,
And then dreames he of ſmelling out a ſute,
And ſometime comes ſhe with a tithe pigs taile,
Tickling a Parſons noſe that lies a ﬂeepe,
And then dreames he of another benefice:
Sometime ſhe gallops ore a ſouldiers noſe,
And then dreames he of cutting forraine throats,
Of breaches ambuſcados, countermines,
Of healthes fiue fadome deepe, and then anon
Drums in his eare: at which he ﬅartes and wakes,
And ſweares a Praier or two and ﬂeepes againe.
This is that Mab that makes maids lie on their backes,
And proues them women of good cariage.
This is the verie Mab that plats the manes of Horſes in the night,
And plats the Elſelocks in foule ﬂuttiſh haire,
Which once vntangled much miſfortune breedes.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Peace, peace, thou talkﬅ of nothing.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: True I talke of dreames,
Which are the Children of an idle braine,
Begot of nothing but vaine fantaﬁe,
Which is as thinne a ſubﬅance as the aire,
And more inconﬅant than the winde,
Which wooes euen now the froſē bowels of the north,
And being angred puffes away in haﬅe,
Turning his face to the dew-dropping ſouth.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Come, come, this winde doth blow vs from our ſelues.
Supper is done and we ſhall come too late.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: I feare too earlie, for my minde miſgiues
Some conſequence is hanging in the ﬅars,
Which bitterly begins his fearefull date
With this nights reuels, and expiers the terme
Of a diſpiſed life, cloſde in this breaﬅ,
By ſome vntimelie forfet of vile death.
But he that hath the ﬅeerage of my courſe
Direƈts my ſaile, on luﬅie Gentlemen.

scene.stagedir: Enter old Capulet with the Ladies.

speech.speaker: Capu:
speech.line: Welcome Gentlemen, welcome Gentlemen,
Ladies that haue their toes vnplagud with Corns
Will haue about with you, ah ha my Miﬅreﬀes,
Which of you all will now refuſe to dance?
Shee that makes daintie, ſhee Ile ſweare hath Corns.
Am I come neere you now, welcome Gentlemen, welcome,
More lights you knaues, & turn theſe tables vp,
And quench the fire the roome is growne too hote.
Ah ﬁrra, this vnlookt for ſport comes well,
Nay ﬁt, nay ﬁt, good Coſen Capulet:
For you and I are paﬅ our ﬅanding dayes,
How long is it ﬁnce you and I were in a Maske?

speech.speaker: Coſ:
speech.line: By Ladie ﬁr tis thirtie yeares at leaﬅ.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Tis not ſo much, tis not ſo much.
Tis ﬁnce the mariage of Lucentio,
Come Pentecoﬅ as quicklie as it will,
Some fiue and twentie yeares, and then we maskt.

speech.speaker: Coſ:
speech.line: Tis more, tis more, his ſonne is elder far.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Will you tell me that it cannot be ſo,
His ſonne was but a Ward three yeares agoe,
Good youths I faith. Oh youth’s a iolly thing.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: What Ladie is that that doth inrich the hand
Of yonder Knight? O ſhee doth teach the torches to burne bright!
It ſeemes ſhe hangs vpon the cheeke of night,
Like a rich iewell in an Aethiops eare,
Beautie too rich for vſe, for earth too deare:
So ſhines a ſnow-white Swan trouping with Crowes,
As this faire Ladie ouer her fellowes ſhowes.
The meaſure done, ile watch her place of ﬅand,
And touching hers, make happie my rude hand
Did my heart loue till now? Forſweare it ﬁght,
I neuer ſaw true beautie till this night.

speech.speaker: Tib:
speech.line: This by his voice ſhould be a Mountague,
Fetch me my rapier boy. What dares the ﬂaue
Come hither couer’d with an Anticke face,
To ſcorne and ieere at our ſolemnitie?
Now by the ﬅocke and honor of my kin,
To ﬅrike him dead I hold it for no ﬁn.

speech.speaker: Ca:
speech.line: Why how now Coſen, wherfore ﬅorme you ſo.

speech.speaker: Ti:
speech.line: Vncle this is a Mountague our foe,
A villaine that is hether come in ſpight,
To mocke at our ſolemnitie this night.

speech.speaker: Ca:
speech.line: Young Romeo, is it not?

speech.speaker: Ti:
speech.line: It is that villaine Romeo.

speech.speaker: Ca:
speech.line: Let him alone, he beares him like a portly gentleman,
And to ſpeake truth, Verona brags of him,
As of a vertuous and well gouern’d youth:
I would not for the wealth of all this towne,
Here in mv houſe doo him diſparagement:
Therefore be quiet take no note of him,
Beare a faire preſence, and put off theſe frownes,
An ill beſeeming ſemblance for a feaﬅ.

speech.speaker: Ti:
speech.line: It fits when ſuch a villaine is a gueﬅ,
Ile not indure him.

speech.speaker: Ca:
speech.line: He ſhalbe indured, goe to I ſay, he ſhall,
Am I the Maﬅer of the houſe or you?
You’le not indure him? God ſhall mend my ſoule
You’le make a mutenie amongﬅ my gueﬅs,
You’le ſet Cocke a hoope, you’le be the man.

speech.speaker: Ti:
speech.line: Vncle tis a ſhame,

speech.speaker: Ca:
speech.line: Goe too, you are a ſaucie knaue.
This tricke will ſcath you one day I know what.
Well ſaid my hartes. Be quiet:
More light Ye knaue, or I will make you quiet.

speech.speaker: Tibalt:
speech.line: Patience perforce with wilfull choller meeting,
Makes my fleſh tremble in their different greetings:
I will withdraw, but this intruﬁon ſhall
Now ſeeming ſweet, conuert to bitter gall.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: If I prophane with my vnworthie hand,
This holie ſhrine, the gentle ﬁnne is this:
My lips two bluſhing Pilgrims ready ﬅand,
To ſmooth the rough touch with a gentle kiﬀe.

speech.speaker: Iuli:
speech.line: Good Pilgrime you doe wrong your hand too much,
Which mannerly deuotion ſhewes in this:
For Saints haue hands which holy Palmers touch,
And Palme to Palme is holy Palmers kiﬀe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Haue not Saints lips, and holy Palmers too?

speech.speaker: Iuli:
speech.line: Yes Pilgrime lips that they muﬅ vſe in praier.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Why then faire ſaint, let lips do what hands doo,
They pray, yeeld thou, leaﬅ faith turne to diſpaire.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: Saints doe not mooue though: grant nor praier forſake.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Then mooue not till my praiers effeƈt I take.
Thus from my lips, by yours my ﬁn is purgde.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: Then haue my lips the ﬁn that they haue tooke.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Sinne from my lips, O treſpaﬀe ſweetly vrgde!
Giue me my ﬁnne againe.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: You kiﬀe by the booke.

line.emph: Madame your mother calles.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: What is her mother?

line.emph: Marrie Batcheler her mother is the Ladie of the houſe, and a good Lady, and a wiſe, and a vertuous. I nurﬅ her daughter that you talkt withall, I tell you, he that ca lay hold of her ſhall haue the chinkes.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Is ſhe a Mountague? Oh deare account,
My life is my foes thrall.

speech.speaker: Ca:
speech.line: Nay gentlemen prepare not to be gone,
We haue a trifling fooliſh banquet towards.
I pray you let me intreat you. Is it ſo?
Well then I thanke you honeﬅ Gentlemen,
I promiſe you but for your company,
I would haue bin a bed an houre agoe:
Light to my chamber hoe.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Nurſe, what is yonder Gentleman?

line.emph: The ſonne and heire of old Tiberio.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Whats he that now is going out of dore?

line.emph: That as I thinke is yong Petruchio.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Whats he that followes there that would not dance?

line.emph: I know not.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Goe learne his name, if he be maried,
My graue is like to be my wedding bed.

line.emph: His name is Romeo and a Mountague, the onely ſonne of your great enemie.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: My onely Loue ſprung from my onely hate,
Too early ſeene vnknowne, and knowne too late:
Prodigious birth of loue is this to me,
That I ſhould loue a loathed enemie.

line.emph: VVhats this? whats that?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Nothing Nurſe but a rime I learnt euen now of oue I dancﬅ with.

line.emph: Come your mother ﬅaies for you. Ile goe a long with you.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Shall I goe forward and my heart is here?
Turne backe dull earth and finde thy Center out.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Romeo, my coſen Romeo.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Doeﬅ thou heare he is wiſe,
Vpon my life he hath ﬅolne him home to bed.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: He came this way, and leapt this Orchard wall.
Call good Mercutio.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Call, nay Ile coniure too.

Romeo, madman, humors, paſsion, liuer, appeare thou in likenes of a ﬁgh: ſpeek but one rime & I am ſatiſfied, cry but ay me. Pronounce but Loue and Doue, ſpeake to my goﬃp Venus one faire word, one nickname for her purblinde ſonne and heire young Abraham: Cupid hee that ſhot ſo trim when young King Cophetua loued the begger wench. Hee heares me not. I coniure thee by Roſalindes bright eye, high forehead, and ſcarlet lip, her prettie foote, ﬅraight leg, and quiuering thigh, and the demaines that there adiacent lie, that in thy likeneﬀe thou appeare to vs.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: If he doe heare thee thou wilt anger him.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Tut this cannot anger him, marrie if one ſhuld raiſe a ſpirit in his Miﬅris circle of ſome ﬅrange faſhion, making it there to ﬅand till ſhe had laid it, and coniurde it downe, that were ſome ſpite. My inuocation is faire and honeﬅ, and in his Miﬅris name I coniure onely but to raiſe vp him.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Well he hath hid himſelfe amongﬅ thoſe trees,
To be conſorted with the humerous night.
Blinde in his loue, and beﬅ befits the darke.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: If loue be blind, loue will not hit the marke,
Now will he ﬁt vnder a Medler tree,
And wiſh his Miﬅris were that kinde of fruite,
As maides call Medlers when they laugh alone.
Ah Romeo that ſhe were, ah that ſhe were
An open Et cætera, thou a poprin Peare.
Romeo God night, il’e to my trundle bed:
This field bed is too cold for mee.
Come lets away, for tis but vaine,
To ſeeke him here that meanes not to be found.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: He ieﬅs at ſcars that neuer felt a wound:
But ſoft, what light forth yonder window breakes?
It is the Eaﬅ, and Iuliet is the Sunne,
Ariſe faire S nne, and kill the enuious Moone
That is alreadie ﬁcke and pale with griefe:
That thou her maid, art far more faire than ſhe.
Be not her maide ﬁnce ſhe is enuious,
Her veﬅall liuerie is but pale and greene,
And none but fooles doe weare it, caﬅ it off.
She ſpeakes, but ſhe ſayes nothing. What of that?
Her eye diſcourſeth, I will anſwere it.
I am too bold, tis not to me ſhe ſpeakes,
Two of the faireﬅ ﬅarres in all the skies,
Hauing ſome buﬁnes, doe entreat her eyes
To twinckle in their ſpheares till they returne.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head,
The brightnes of her cheekes would ſhame thoſe ﬅars:
As day-light doth a Lampe, her eyes in heauen,
Would through the airie region ﬅreame ſo bright,
That birdes would ﬁng, and thinke it were not night.
Oh now ſhe leanes her cheekes vpon her hand,
I would I were the gloue to that ſame hand,
That I might kiﬀe that cheeke.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Ay me.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: She ſpeakes, Oh ſpeake againe bright Angell:
For thou are as glorious to this night beeing ouer my head,
As is a winged meﬀenger of heauen
Vnto the white vpturned woondring eyes,
Of mortals that fall backe to gaze on him,
When he beﬅrides the laﬁe pacing cloudes,
And ſailes vpon the boſome of the aire.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Ah Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?
Denie thy Father, and refuſe thy name,
Or if thou wilt not be but ſworne my loue,
And il’e no longer be a Capulet.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Shall I heare more, or ſhall I ſpeake to this?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Tis but thy name that is mine enemie.
Whats Mountague? It is nor hand nor foote,
Nor arme, nor face, nor any other part.
Whats in a name? That which we call a Roſe,
By any other name would ſmell as ſweet:
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo cald,
Retaine the diuine perfeƈtion he owes:
Without that title Romeo part thy name,
And for that name which is no part of thee,
Take all I haue.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I take thee at thy word,
Call me but loue, and il’e be new Baptiſde,
Henceforth I neuer will be Romeo.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: What man art thou, that thus beskrind in night,
Doeﬅ ﬅumble on my counſaile?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: By a name I know not how to tell thee.
My name deare Saint is hatefull to my ſelfe,
Becauſe it is an enemie to thee.
Had I it written I would teare the word.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: My eares haue not yet drunk a hundred words
Of that tongues vtterance, yet I know the ſound:
Art thou not Romeo and a Mountague?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Neyther faire Saint, if eyther thee diſpleaſe.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: How camﬅ thou hether, tell me and wherefore?
The Orchard walles are high and hard to clime,
And the place death conﬁdering who thou art,
If any of my kinſmen finde thee here.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: By loues light winges did I oreperch theſ wals,
For ﬅonie limits cannot hold loue out,
And what loue can doo, that dares loue attempt,
Therefore thy kinſmen are no let to me.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: If they doe finde thee they will murder thee.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Alas there lies more perrill in thine eyes,
Then twentie of their ſwords, looke thou but ſweete,
And I am proofe againﬅ their enmitie.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I would not for the world they ſhuld find thee here.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: I haue nights cloak to hide thee from their ﬁght,
And but thou loue me let them finde me here:
For life were better ended by their hate,
Than death proroged wanting of thy loue.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: By whoſe direƈtions foundﬅ thou out this place.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: By loue, who firﬅ did prompt me to enquire,
I he gaue me counſaile and I lent him eyes.
I am no Pilot: yet wert thou as farre
As that vaﬅ ſhore, waſht with the furtheﬅ ſea,
I would aduenture for ſuch Marchandiſe.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Thou knowﬅ the maſke of night is on my face
Els would a Maiden bluſh bepaint my cheeks:
For that which thou haﬅe heard me ſpeake to night,
Faine would I dwell on forme, faine faine denie,
What I haue ſpoke: but farewell complements.
Doeﬅ thou loue me? Nay I know thou wilt ſay I,
And I will take thy word: but if thou ſwearﬅ,
Thou maieﬅ proue falſe:
At Louers periuries they ſay Ioue ſmiles.
Ah gentle Romeo, if thou loue pronounce it faithfully:
Or if thou thinke I am too eaſely wonne,
Il’e frowne and ſay thee nay and be peruerſe,
So thou wilt wooe: but els not for the world,
In truth faire Mountague, I am too fond,
And therefore thou maieﬅ thinke my hauiour light:
But truﬅ me gentleman Ile proue more true,
Than they that haue more cunning to be ﬅrange.
I ſhould haue bin ﬅrange I muﬅ confeﬀe,
But that thou ouer-heardﬅ ere I was ware
My true loues Paſsion: therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yeelding to light loue,
Which the darke night hath ſo diſcouered.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: By yonder bleﬀed Moone I ſweare,
That tips with ﬁluer all theſe fruit trees tops.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: O ſweare not by the Moone the vnconﬅant Moone,
That monthlie changeth in her circled orbe,
Leaﬅ that thy loue proue likewiſe variable.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Now by

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Nay doo not ſweare at all,
Or if thou ſweare, ſweare by thy glorious ſelfe,
Which art the God of my Idolatrie,
And il’e beleeue thee.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: If my true harts loue

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Sweare not at al, though I doo ioy in thee,
I haue ſmall ioy in this contraƈt to night,
It is too raſh, too ſodaine, too vnaduiſde,
Too like the lightning that doth ceaſe to bee
Ere one can ſay it lightens. heare ſome comming,
Deare loue adew, ſweet Mountague be true,
Stay but a little and il’e come againe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: O bleﬀed bleﬀed night, I feare being night,
All this is but a dreame I heare and ſee,
Too flattering true to be ſubﬅantiall.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Three wordes good Romeo and good night indeed.
If that thy bent of loue be honourable?
Thy purpoſe marriage, ſend me word to morrow
By one that il’e procure to come to thee:
Where and what time thou wilt performe that right,
And al my fortunes at thy foote il’e lay,
And follow thee my Lord through out the world.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Loue goes toward loue like ſchoole boyes from their bookes,
But loue from loue, to ſchoole with heauie lookes.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Romeo, Romeo, O for a falkners voice,
To lure this Taﬀell gentle backe againe:
Bondage is hoarſe and may not crie aloud,
Elſ would I teare the Caue where Eccho lies
And make her airie voice as hoarſe as mine,
With repetition of my Romeos name.
Romeo?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: It is my ſoule that calles vpon my name,
How ﬁluer ſweet ſound louers tongues in night,

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Romeo?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Madame.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: At what a clocke to morrow ſhall I ſend?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: At the houre of nine.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I will not faile, tis twentie yeares till then.
Romeo I haue forgot why I did call thee backe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Let me ﬅay here till you remember it.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I ſhall forget to haue thee ﬅill ﬅaie here,
Remembring how I loue thy companie.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: And il’e ﬅay ﬅill to haue thee ﬅill forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Tis almoﬅ morning I would haue thee gone,
And yet no further then a wantons bird,
Who lets it hop a little from her hand,
Like a pore priſoner in his twiﬅed giues,
And with a ﬁlke thred puls it backe againe,
Too louing iealous of his libertie.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: Would I were thy bird.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Sweet ſo would I,
Yet I ſhould kill thee with much cherriſhing thee.
Good night, good night, parting is ſuch ſweet ſorrow,
That I ſhall ſay good night till it be morrow.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Sleepe dwell vpon thine eyes, peace on thy breaﬅ,
I would that I were ﬂeep and peace of ſweet to reﬅ.
Now will I to my Ghoﬅly fathers Cell,
His help to craue, and my good hap to tell.

speech.speaker: Frier:
speech.line: The gray ey’d morne ſmiles on the frowning night,
Checkring the Eaﬅerne clouds with ﬅreakes of light,
And flecked darkenes like a drunkard reeles,
From forth daies path, and Titans fierie wheeles:
Now ere the Sunne aduance his burning eye,
The world to cheare, and nights darke dew to drie.
We muﬅ vp fill this oaﬁer Cage of ours,
With balefull weeds, and precious iuyced flowers.
Oh mickle is the powerfull grace that lies
In hearbes, plants, ﬅones, and their true qualities:
For nought ſo vile, that vile on earth doth liue,
But to the earth ſome ſpeciall good doth giue:
Nor nought ſo good, but ﬅraind from that faire vſe,
Reuolts to vice and ﬅumbles on abuſe:
Vertue it ſelfe turnes vice being miſapplied,
And vice ſometimes by aƈtion dignified.
Within the infant rinde of this ſmall ﬂower,
Poyſon hath reﬁdence, and medecine power:
For this being ſmelt too, with that part cheares ech hart,
Being taﬅed ﬂaies all ſences with the hart.
Two ſuch oppoſed foes incampe them ﬅill,
In man as well as herbes, grace and rude will,
And where the worſer is predominant,
Full ſoone the canker death eats vp that plant.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Good morrow to my Ghoﬅly Confeﬀor.

speech.speaker: Fri:
speech.line: Benedicte, what earlie tongue ſo ſoone ſaluteth me?
Yong ſonne it argues a diﬅempered head,
So ſoone to bid good morrow to my bed.
Care keepes his watch in euerie old mans eye,
And where care lodgeth, ﬂeep can neuer lie:
But where vnbruſed youth with vnﬅuft braines
Doth couch his limmes, there golden ﬂeepe remaines:
Therefore thy earlines doth me aﬀure,
Thou art vprowl’d by ſome diﬅemperature.
Or if not ſo, then here I hit it righ
Our Romeo hath not bin a bed to night.

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: The laﬅ was true, the ſweeter reﬅ was mine.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: God pardon ﬁn, wert thou with Roſaline?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: With Roſaline my Ghoﬅly father no,
I haue forgot that name, and that names woe.

speech.speaker: Fri:
speech.line: Thats my good ſonne: but where haﬅ thou bin then?

speech.speaker: Ro:
speech.line: I tell thee ere thou aske it me againe,
I haue bin feaﬅing with mine enemie:
Where on the ſodaine one hath wounded mee
Thats by me wounded, both our remedies
With in thy help and holy phiﬁcke lies,
I beare no hatred bleﬀed man: for loe
My interceſsion likewiſe ﬅeades my foe.

speech.speaker: Frier:
speech.line: Be plaine my ſonne and homely in thy drift,
Ridling confeſsion findes but ridling ſhrift.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Then plainely know my harts deare loue is ſet
On the faire daughter of rich Capulet:
As mine on hers, ſo hers likewiſe on mine,
And all combind, ſaue what thou muﬅ combine
By holy marriage: where, and when, and how,
We met, we woo’d, and made exchange of vowes,
Il’e tell thee as I paﬀe: But this I pray,
That thou conſent to marrie vs to day.

speech.speaker: Fri:
speech.line: Holy S. Francis, what a change is here?
Is Roſaline whome thou didﬅ loue ſo deare
So ſoone forſooke, lo yong mens loue then lies
Not truelie in their harts, but in their eyes.
Ieſu Maria, what a deale of brine
Hath waſht thy ſallow cheekes for Roſaline?
How much ſalt water caﬅ away in waﬅe,
To ſeaſon loue, that of loue doth not taﬅe.
The ſunne not yet thy ﬁghes from heauen cleares,
Thy old grones ring yet in my ancient eares,
And loe vpon thy cheeke the ﬅaine doth ﬁt,
Of an old teare that is not waſht off yet.
If euer thou wert thus, and theſe woes thine,
Thou and theſe woes were all for Roſaline,
And art thou changde, pronounce this ſentence then
Women may fal, when ther’s no ﬅrength in men.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Thou chidﬅ me oft for louing Roſoline

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: For doating, not for louing, pupill mine.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: And badﬅ me burie loue.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Not in a graue,
To lay one in another out to haue.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I pree thee chide not, ſhe whom I loue now
Doth grace for grace, and loue for loue allow:
The other did not ſo.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Oh ſhe knew well
Thy loue did read by rote, and could not ſpell.
But come yong Wauerer, come goe with mee,
In one reſpeƈt Ile thy aſsiﬅant bee:
For this alliaunce may ſo happie proue,
To turne your Houſholds rancour to pure loue.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Why whats become of Romeo? came he not home to night?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Not to his Fathers, I ſpake with his man.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Ah that ſame pale hard hearted wench, that Roſaline
Torments him ſo, that he will ſure run mad.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Tybalt the Kinſman of olde Capolet
Hath ſent a Letter to his Fathers Houſe:
Some Challenge on my life.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Romeo will anſwere it.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: I, anie man that can write may anſwere a letter.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Nay, he will anſwere the letters maﬅer if hee bee challenged.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Who, Romeo? why he is alreadie dead: ﬅabd with a white wenches blacke eye, ſhot thorough the eare with a loue ſong, the verie pinne of his heart cleft with the blinde bow-boyes but-ſhaft. And is he a man to encounter Tybalt?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Why what is Tybalt?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: More than the prince of cattes I can tell you. Oh he is the couragious captaine of complements. Catſo, he fightes as you ﬁng pricke-ſong, keepes time dyﬅance and proportion, reﬅs me his minum reﬅ one two and the thirde in your boſome, the very butcher of a ﬁlken button, a Duelliﬅ a Duelliﬅ, a gentleman of the very firﬅ houſe of the firﬅ and ſecond cauſe, ah the immortall Paﬀado, the Punto reuerſo, the Hay.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: The what?

speech.speaker: Me:
speech.line: The Poxe of ſuch limping antique affeƈting fantaﬅicoes theſe new tuners of accents. by Ieſu a very good blade, a very tall man, a very good whoore. Why graundﬁr is not this a miſerable caſe that we ſhould be ﬅil affliƈted with theſe ﬅrange flies: theſe faſhionmongers, theſe pardonmees, that ﬅand ſo much on the new forme, that they cannot ﬁtte at eaſe on the old bench. Oh their bones, theyr bones.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Heere comes Romeo.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Without his Roe, like a dryed Hering. O fleſh fleſh how art thou fiſhified. Sirra now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowdin: Laura to his Lady was but a kitchin drudg, yet ſhe had a better loue to berime her: Dido a dowdy Cleopatra a Gypﬁe, Hero and Hellen hildings and harletries: Thiſbie a gray eye or ſo, but not to the purpoſe. Signior Romeo bon iour, there is a French curteﬁe to your French ﬂop: yee gaue vs the counterfeit fairely yeﬅernight.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: What counterfeit I pray you?

speech.speaker: Me:
speech.line: The ﬂip the ﬂip, can you not conceiue?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I cry you mercy my buﬁnes was great, and in ſuch a caſe as mine, a man may ﬅraine curteﬁe.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Oh thats as much as to ſay as ſuch a caſe as yours wil conﬅraine a man to bow in the hams.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: A moﬅ curteous expoﬁtion.

speech.speaker: Me:
speech.line: Why I am the very pinke of curteﬁe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Pinke for flower?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Right.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Then is my Pumpe well flour’d:

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Well ſaid, follow me nowe that ieﬅ till thou haﬅ worne out thy Pumpe, that when the ﬁngle ſole of it is worn the ieﬅ may remaine after the wearing ſolie ﬁnguler.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: O ﬁngle ſoald ieﬅ ſolie ﬁnguler for the ﬁnglenes.

speech.speaker: Me:
speech.line: Come between vs good Benuolio, for my wits faile.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Swits and ſpurres, ſwits & ſpurres, or Ile cry a match.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Nay if thy wits runne the wildgooſe chaſe, I haue done: for I am ſure thou haﬅ more of the gooſe in one of thy wits, than I haue in al my fiue: Was I with you there for the gooſe?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Thou wert neuer with me for any thing, when thou wert not with me for the gooſe.

speech.speaker: Me:
speech.line: Ile bite thee by the eare for that ieﬅ.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Nay good gooſe bite not.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Why thy wit is a bitter ſweeting, a moﬅ ſharp ſauce

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: And was it not well ſeru’d in to a ſweet gooſe?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Oh heere is a witte of Cheuerell that ﬅretcheth from an ynch narrow to an ell broad.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I ﬅretcht it out for the word broad, which added to the gooſe, proues thee faire and wide a broad gooſe.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Why is not this better now than groning for loue? why now art thou ſociable, nowe art thou thy ſelfe, nowe art thou what thou art, as wel by arte as nature. This driueling loue is like a great naturall, that runs vp and downe to hide his bable in a hole.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Stop there.

speech.speaker: Me:
speech.line: Why thou wouldﬅ haue me ﬅopp my tale againﬅ the haire.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Thou wouldﬅ haue made thy tale too long?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Tut man thou art deceiued, I meant to make it ſhort, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale? and meant indeed to occupie the argument no longer.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Heers goodly geare.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: A ſaile, a ſaile, a ſaile.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Two, two, a ſhirt and a ſmocke.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Peter, pree thee giue me my fan

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Pree thee doo good Peter, to hide her face: for her fanne is the fairer of the two.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: God ye goodmorrow Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: God ye good den faire Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Is it godye gooden I pray you.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Tis no leﬀe I aﬀure you, for the baudie hand of the diall is euen now vpon the pricke of noone.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Fie, what a man is this?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: A Gentleman Nurſe, that God hath made for himſelfe to marre.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: By my troth well ſaid: for himſelfe to marre quoth he? I pray you can anie of you tell where one maie finde yong Romeo?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I can: but yong Romeo will bee elder when you haue found him, than he was when you ſought him. I am the yongeﬅ of that name for fault of a worſe.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Well ſaid.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Yea, is the worﬅ well? mas well noted, wiſely, wiſely.

speech.speaker: Nu:
speech.line: If you be he ﬁr, I deﬁre ſome conference with ye.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: O, belike ſhe meanes to inuite him to ſupper.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: So ho. A baud, a baud, a baud.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Why what haﬅ found man?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: No hare ﬁr, vnleﬀe it be a hare in a lenten pye, that is ſomewhat ﬅale and hoare ere it be eaten.
speech.stagedir: He walkes by them, and ﬁngs.
speech.line: And an olde hare hore, and an olde hare hore is verie good meate in Lent:
But a hare thats hoare is too much for a ſcore, if it hore ere it be ſpent.
Youl come to your fathers to ſupper?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I will.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Farewell ancient Ladie, farewell ſweete Ladie.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Marry farewell. Pray what ſaucie merchant was this that was ſo full of his roperipe?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: A gentleman Nurſe that loues to heare himſelfe talke, and will ſpeake more in an houre than hee will ﬅand to in a month.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: If hee ﬅand to anie thing againﬅ mee, Ile take him downe if he were luﬅier than he is: if I cannot take him downe, Ile finde them that ſhall: I am none of his flurtgills, I am none of his skaines mates.
speech.stagedir: She turnes to Peter her man.
speech.line: And thou like a knaue muﬅ ﬅand by, and ſee euerie Iacke vſe me at his pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Pet:
speech.line: I ſee no bodie vſe you at his pleaſure, if I had, I would ſoone haue drawen: you know my toole is as ſoone out as anothers if I ſee time and place.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Now afore God he hath ſo vext me, that euerie member about me quiuers: ſcuruie Iacke. But as I ſaid, my Ladie bad me ſeeke ye out, and what ſhee bad me tell yee, that Ile keepe to my ſelfe: but if you ſhould lead her into a fooles paradice as they ſaye, it were a verie groﬀe kinde of behauior as they ſay, for the Gentlewoman is yong. Now if you ſhould deale doubly with her, it were verie weake dealing, and not to be offered to anie Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Nurſe, commend me to thy Ladie, tell her I proteﬅ.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Good heart: yfaith Ile tell her ſo: oh ſhe will be a ioyfull woman.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Why, what wilt thou tell her?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: That you doo proteﬅ: which (as I take it) is a Gentlemanlike proffer.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Bid her get leaue tomorrow morning
To come to ſhrift to Frier Laurence cell:
And ﬅay thou Nurſe behinde the Abbey wall,
My man ſhall come to thee, and bring along
The cordes, made like a tackled ﬅaire,
Which to the hightop gallant of my ioy
Muﬅ be my conduƈt in the ſecret night.
Hold, take that for thy paines.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: No, not a penie truly.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I ſay you ſhall not chuſe.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Well, to morrow morning ſhe ſhall not faile.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Farewell, be truﬅie, and Ile quite thy paine.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Peter, take my fanne, and goe before.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: THe clocke ﬅroke nine when I did ſend my Nurﬀe
In halfe an houre ſhe promiﬅ to returne.
Perhaps ſhe cannot finde him. Thats not ſo.
Oh ſhe is lazie, Loues heralds ſhould be thoughts,
And runne more ſwift, than haﬅie powder fierd,
Doth hurrie from the fearfull Cannons mouth.
Oh now ſhe comes. Tell me gentle Nurſe,
What ſayes my Loue?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Oh I am wearie, let mee reﬅ a while. Lord how my bones ake. Oh wheres my man? Giue me ſome aqua vitæ.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I would thou hadﬅ my bones, and I thy newes.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Fie, what a iaunt haue I had: and my backe a tother ﬁde. Lord, Lord, what a caſe am I in.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: But tell me ſweet Nurſe, what ſayes Romeo?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Romeo, nay, alas you cannot chuſe a man. Hees no bodie, he is not the Flower of curteﬁe, he is not a proper man: and for a hand, and a foote, and a baudie, wel go thy way wench, thou haﬅ it ifaith. Lord, Lord, how my head beates?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: What of all this? tell me what ſayes he to our mariage?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Marry he ſayes like an honeﬅ Gentleman, and a kinde, and I warrant a vertuous: wheres your Mother?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Lord, Lord, how odly thou replieﬅ? He ſaies like a kinde Gentleman, and an honeﬅ, and a vertuous; wheres your mother?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Marry come vp, cannot you ﬅay a while? is this the poulteﬀe for mine aking boanes? next arrant youl haue done, euen doot your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Nay ﬅay ſweet Nurſe, I doo intreate thee now,
What ſayes my Loue, my Lord, my Romeo?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Goe, hye you ﬅraight to Friar Laurence Cell,
And frame a ſcuſe that you muﬅ goe to ſhrift:
There ﬅayes a Bridegroome to make you a Bride.
Now comes the wanton blood vp in your cheekes,
I muﬅ prouide a ladder made of cordes,
With which your Lord muﬅ clime a birdes neﬅ ſoone.
I muﬅ take paines to further your delight,
But you muﬅ beare the burden ſoone at night.
Doth this newes pleaſe you now?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: How doth her latter words reuiue my hart.
Thankes gentle Nurſe, diſpatch thy buﬁnes,
And Ile not faile to meete my Romeo.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Now Father Laurence, in thy holy grant
Conﬁﬅs the good of me and Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Without more words I will doo all I may,
To make you happie if in me it lye.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: This morning here ſhe pointed we ſhould meet,
And conſumate thoſe neuer parting bands,
Witnes of our harts loue by ioyning hands,
And come ſhe will.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: I geﬀe ſhe will indeed,
Youths loue is quicke, ſwifter than ſwifteﬅ ſpeed.
speech.stagedir: Enter Iuliet ſomewhat faﬅ, and embraceth Romeo.
speech.line: See where ſhe comes.
So light of foote nere hurts the troden flower:
Of loue and ioy, ſee ſee the ſoueraigne power.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: My Iuliet welcome. As doo waking eyes
(Cloaſd in Nights myﬅs) attend the frolicke Day,
So Romeo hath expeƈted Iuliet,
And thou art come.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: I am (if I be Day)
Come to my Sunne: ſhine foorth, and make me faire.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: All beauteous fairnes dwelleth in thine eyes.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Romeo from thine all brightnes doth ariſe.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Come wantons, come, the ﬅealing houres do paﬀe
Defer imbracements till ſome fitrer time,
Part for a while, you ſhall not be alone,
Till holy Church haue ioynd ye both in one.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Lead holy Father, all delay ſeemes long.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Make haﬅ, make haﬅ, this lingring doth vs wrong.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: O, ſoft and faire makes ſweeteﬅ worke they ſay.
Haﬅ is a common hindrer in croﬀe way.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: I pree thee good Mercutio lets retire,
The day is hot, the Capels are abroad.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Thou art like one of thoſe, that when hee comes into the confines of a tauerne, claps me his rapier on the boord, and ſayes, God ſend me no need of thee: and by the operation of the next cup of wine, he drawes it on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Am I like ſuch a one?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Go too, thou art as hot a Iacke being mooude, and as ſoone mooude to be moodie, and as ſoone moodie to be mooud.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: And what too?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Nay, and there were two ſuch, wee ſhould haue none ſhortly. Didﬅ not thou fall out with a man for cracking of nuts, hauing no other reaſon, but becauſe thou hadﬅ haﬁll eyes? whay eye but ſuch an eye would haue pickt out ſuch a quarrell? With another for coughing, becauſe hee wakd thy dogge that laye a ﬂeepe in the Sunne? With a Taylor for wearing his new dublet before Eaﬅer: and with another for tying his new ſhoes with olde ribands. And yet thou wilt forbid me of quarrelling.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: By my head here comes a Capolet.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: By my heele I care not.

speech.speaker: Tyb:
speech.line: Gentlemen a word with one of you.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: But one word with one of vs? You had beﬅ couple it with ſomewhat, and make it a word and a blow.

speech.speaker: Tyb:
speech.line: I am apt enough to that if I haue occaﬁon.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Could you not take occaﬁon?

speech.speaker: Tyb:
speech.line: Mercutio thou conſorts with Romeo?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Conſort Zwounes conſort? the ﬂaue wil make fidlers of vs. If you doe ﬁrra, look for nothing but diſcord: For heeres my fiddle-ﬅicke.

speech.speaker: Tyb:
speech.line: Well peace be with you, heere comes my man.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: But Ile be hanged if he weare your lyuery: Mary go before into the field, and he may be your follower, ſo in that ſence your worſhip may call him man.

speech.speaker: Tyb:
speech.line: Romeo the hate I beare to thee can affoord no better words then theſe, thou art a villaine.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Tybalt, the loue I beare to thee, doth excuſe the appertaining rage to ſuch a word: villaine am I none, therefore I well perceiue thou knowﬅ me not.

speech.speaker: Tyb:
speech.line: Bace boy this cannot ſerue thy turne, and therefore drawe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I doe proteﬅ I neuer iniured thee, but loue thee better than thou canﬅ deuiſe, till thou ſhalt know the reaſon of my loue.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: O diſhonorable vile ſubmiﬃon. Allaﬅockado caries it away. You Ratcatcher, come backe, come backe.

speech.speaker: Tyb:
speech.line: What wouldeﬅ with me?

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Nothing King of Cates, but borrow one of your nine liues, therefore come drawe your rapier out of your ſcabard, leaﬅ mine be about your eares ere you be aware.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Stay Tibalt, hould Mercutio: Benuolio beate downe their weapons.

scene.stagedir: Tibalt vnder Romeos arme thruﬅs Mercutio, in and flyes.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Is he gone, hath hee nothing? A poxe on your houſes.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: What art thou hurt man, the wound is not deepe.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Noe not ſo deepe as a Well, nor ſo wide as a barne doore, but it will ſerue I warrant. What meant you to come betweene vs? I was hurt vnder your arme.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I did all for the beﬅ.

speech.speaker: Me:
speech.line: A poxe of your houſes, I am fairely dreﬅ. Sirra goe fetch me a Surgeon.

speech.speaker: Boy:
speech.line: I goe my Lord.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: I am pepperd for this world, I am ſped yfaith, he hath made wormes meate of me, & ye aske for me to morrow you ſhall finde me a graue man. A poxe of your houſes, I ſhall be fairely mounted vpon foure mens ſhoulders: For your houſe of the Mountegues and the Capolets: and then ſome peaſantly rogue, ſome Sexton, ſome baſe ﬂaue ſhall write my Epitapth, that Tybalt came and broke the Princes Lawe, and Mercutio was ﬂaine for the firﬅ and ſecond cauſe. Wher’s the Surgeon?

speech.speaker: Boy:
speech.line: Hee’s come ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Mer:
speech.line: Now heele keepe a mumbling in my guts on the other ﬁde, come Benuolio, lend me thy hand: a poxe of your houſes.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: This Gentleman the Princes neere Alie.
My very frend hath tane this mortall wound
In my behalfe, my reputation ﬅaind
With Tibalts ﬂaunder, Tybalt that an houre
Hath beene my kinſman. Ah Iuliet
Thy beautie makes me thus effeminate,
And in my temper ſoftens valors ﬅeele.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Ah Romeo Romeo braue Mercutio is dead,
That gallant ſpirit hath a ſpir’d the cloudes,
Which too vntimely ſcornd the lowly earth.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: This daies black fate, on more daies doth depend
This but begins what other dayes muﬅ end.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Heere comes the furious Tibalt backe againe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: A liue in tryumph and Mercutio ﬂaine?
Away to heauen reſpeƈtiue lenity,
And fier eyed fury be my conduƈt now.
Now Tibalt take the villaine backe againe,
Which late thou gau’ﬅ me: for Mercutios ſoule,
Is but a little way aboue the cloudes,
And ﬅaies for thine to beare him company.
Or thou, or I, or both ſhall follow him.

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Romeo away, thou ſeeﬅ that Tibalt’s ﬂaine,
The Citizens approach, away, begone
Thou wilt be taken.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Ah I am fortunes ﬂaue.

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: Wher’s he that ﬂue Mercutio, Tybalt that villaine?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: There is that Tybalt.
Vp ﬁirra goe with vs.

speech.speaker: Pry:
speech.line: Where be the vile beginners of this fray?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Ah Noble Prince I can diſcouer all
The moﬅ vnlucky mannage of this brawle.
Heere lyes the man ﬂaine by yong Romeo,
That ﬂew thy kinſman braue Mercutio,

speech.speaker: M:
speech.line: Tibalt, Tybalt, O my brothers child,
Vnhappie ﬁght? Ah the blood is ſpilt
Of my deare kinſman, Prince as thou art true:
For blood of ours, ſhed bloud of Mountagew.

speech.speaker: Pry:
speech.line: Speake Benuolio who began this fray?

speech.speaker: Ben:
speech.line: Tibalt heere ﬂaine whom Romeos hand did ﬂay,
Romeo who ſpake him fayre bid him bethinke
How nice the quarrell was.
But Tibalt ﬅill perﬁﬅing in his wrong,
The ﬅout Mercutio drewe to calme the ﬅorme,
Which Romeo ſeeing cal’d ﬅay Gentlemen,
And on me cry’d, who drew to part their ﬅrife,
And with his agill arme yong Romeo,
As faﬅ as tung cryde peace, ſought peace to make.
While they were enterchanging thruﬅs and blows,
Vnder yong Romeos laboring arme to part,
The furious Tybalt caﬅ an enuious thruﬅ,
That rid the life of ﬅout Mercutio.
With that he fled, but preſently return’d,
And with his rapier braued Romeo:
That had but newly entertain’d reuenge.
And ere I could draw forth my rapyer
To part their furie, downe did Tybalt fall,
And this way Romeo fled.

speech.speaker: Mo:
speech.line: He is a Mountagew and ſpeakes partiall,
Some twentie of them fought in this Blacke ﬅrife:
And all thoſe twenty could but kill one life.
I doo intreate ſweete Prince thoult iuﬅice giue,
Romeo ﬂew Tybalt, Romeo may not liue.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: And for that offence
Immediately we doo exile him hence.
I haue an intereﬅ in your hates proceeding,
My blood for your rude braules doth lye a bleeding.
But Ile amerce you with ſo large a fine,
That you ſhall all repent the loﬀe of mine.
I will be deafe to pleading and excuſes,
Nor teares nor prayers ſhall purchaſe for abuſes.
Pittie ſhall dwell and gouerne with vs ﬅill:
Mercie to all but murdrers, pardoning none that kill.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Gallop apace, you fierie footed ﬅeedes
To Phœbus manﬁon, ſuch a Waggoner
As Phaeton, would quickly bring you thether,
And ſend in cloudie night immediately.
speech.stagedir: Enter Nurſe wringing her hands, with the ladder of cordes in her lap.
speech.line: But how now Nurſe: O Lord, why lookﬅ thou ſad?
What haﬅ thou there, the cordes?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: I, I, the cordes: alacke we are vndone,
We are vndone, Ladie we are vndone.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: What diuell art thou that torments me thus?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Alack the day, hees dead, hees dead, hees dead.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: This torture ſhould be roard in diſmall hell.
Can heauens be ſo enuious?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Romeo can if heauens cannot.
I ſaw the wound, I ſaw it with mine eyes.
God ſaue the ſample, on his manly breaﬅ:
A bloodie coarſe, a piteous bloodie coarſe,
All pale as aſhes, I ſwounded at the ﬁght.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Ah Romeo, Romeo, what diſaﬅer hap
Hath ſeuerd thee from thy true Juliet?
Ah why ſhou’d Heauen ſo much conſpire with Woe,
Or Fate enuie our happie Marriage,
So ſoone to ſunder vs by timeleﬀe Death?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the beﬅ frend I had,
O honeﬅ Tybalt, curteous Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: What ﬅorme is this that blowes ſo contrarie,
Is Tybalt dead, and Romeo murdered:
My deare loude couſen, and my deareﬅ Lord.
Then let the trumpet ſound a generall doome,
Theſe two being dead, then liuing is there none.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo baniſhed,
Romeo that murdred him is baniſhed.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Ah heauens, did Romeos hand ſhed Tybalts blood?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: It did, it did, alacke the day it did.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: O ſerpents hate, hid with a flowring face:
O painted ſepulcher, including filth.
Was neuer booke containing ſo foule matter,
So fairly bound. Ah, what meant Romeo?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: There is no truth, no faith, no honeﬅie in men:
All falſe, all faithles, periurde, all forſworne.
Shame come to Romeo.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: A bliﬅer on that tung, he was not borne to ſhame:
Vpon his face Shame is aſhamde to ﬁt.
But wherefore villaine didﬅ thou kill my Couſen?
That villaine Couſen would haue kild my husband.
All this is comfort. But there yet remaines
VVorſe than his death, which faine I would forget:
But ah, it preﬀeth to my memorie,
Romeo is baniſhed. Ah that word Baniſhed
Is worſe than death. Romeo is baniſhed,
Is Father, Mother, Tybalt, Iuliet,
All killd, all ﬂaine, all dead, all baniſhed.
Where are my Father and my Mother Nurſe?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: VVeeping and wayling ouer Tybalts coarſe.
VVill you goe to them?

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: I, I when theirs are ſpent,
Mine ſhall he ſhed for Romeos baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Ladie, your Romeo will be here to night,
Ile to him, he is hid at Laurence Cell.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Doo ſo, and beare this Ring to my true Knight,
And bid him come to take his laﬅ farewell.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Romeo come forth, come forth thou fearfull man,
Affliƈtion is enamourd on thy parts,
And thou art wedded to Calamitie.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Father what newes, what is the Princes doome,
VVhat Sorrow craues acquaintance at our hands,
VVhich yet we know not.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Too familiar
Is my yong ſonne with ſuch ſowre companie:
I bring thee tidings of the Princes doome.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: VVhat leﬀe than doomes day is the Princes doome?

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: A gentler iudgement vaniſht from his lips,
Not bodies death, but bodies baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Ha, Baniſhed? be mercifull, ſay death:
For Exile hath more terror in his lookes,
Than death it ſelfe, doo not ſay Baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Hence from Verona art thou baniſhed:
Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: There is no world without Verona walls,
But purgatorie, torture, hell it ſelfe.
Hence baniſhed, is baniſht from the world:
And world exilde is death. Calling death baniſhment,
Thou cutﬅ my head off with a golden axe,
And ſmileﬅ vpon the ﬅroke that murders me.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Oh monﬅrous ﬁnne, O rude vnthankfulnes:
Thy fault our law calls death, but the milde Prince
(Taking thy part) hath ruſhd aﬁde the law,
And turnd that blacke word death to baniſhment:
This is meere mercie, and thou ſeeﬅ it not.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Tis torture and not mercie, heauen is heere
Where Iuliet liues: and euerie cat and dog,
And little mouſe, euerie vnworthie thing
Liue here in heauen, and may looke on her,
But Romeo may not. More validitie,
More honourable ﬅate, more courtſhip liues
In carrion flyes, than Romeo: they may ſeaze
On the white wonder of faire Iuliets skinne,
And ﬅeale immortall kiﬀes from her lips;
But Romeo may not, he is baniſhed.
Flies may doo this, but I from this muﬅ flye.
Oh Father hadﬅ thou no ﬅrong poyſon mixt,
No ſharpe ground knife, no preſent meane of death,
Though nere ſo meane, but baniſhment
To torture me withall: ah, baniſhed.
O Frier, the damned vſe that word in hell:
Howling attends it. How hadﬅ thou the heart,
Being a Diuine, a ghoﬅly Confeﬀor,
A ﬁnne abſoluer, and my frend profeﬅ,
To mangle me with that word, Baniſhment?

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Thou fond mad man, heare me but ſpeake a word.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: O, thou wilt talke againe of Baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Ile giue thee armour to beare off this word,
Aduerﬁties ſweete milke, philoſophie,
To comfort thee though thou be baniſhed.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Yet Baniſhed? hang vp philoſophie,
Vnleﬀe philoſophie can make a Juliet,
Diſplant a Towne, reuerſe a Princes doome,
It helpes not, it preuailes not, talke no more.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: O, now I ſee that madmen haue no eares.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: How ſhould they, when that wiſe men haue no eyes.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Let me diſpute with thee of thy eﬅate.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Thou canﬅ not ſpeak of what thou doﬅ not feele.
Wert thou as young as I, Iuliet thy Loue,
An houre but married, Tybalt murdered.
Doting like me, and like me baniſhed,
Then mightﬅ thou ſpeake, then mightﬅ thou teare thy hayre.
And fall vpon the ground as I doe now,
Taking the meaſure of an vnmade graue.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Romeo ariſe, ﬅand vp thou wilt be taken,
I heare one knocke, ariſe and get thee gone.

speech.speaker: Nu:
speech.line: Hoe Fryer.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Gods will what wilfulnes is this?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Hoe Fryer open the doore,

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: By and by I come. Who is there?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: One from Lady Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Then come neare.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: O holy Fryer, tell mee oh holy Fryer,
Where is my Ladies Lord? Wher's Romeo?

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: There on the ground, with his owne teares made drunke.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: O he is euen in my Miﬅreﬀe caſe.
Iuﬅ in her caſe. Oh wofull ﬁimpathy,
Pitteous predicament, euen ſo lyes ſhee,
Weeping and blubbring, blubbring and weeping:
Stand vp, ﬅand vp, ﬅand and you be a man.
For Iuliets ſake, for her ſake riſe and ﬅand,
Why ſhould you fall into ſo deep an O.

speech.speaker: Romeo:
speech.line: Nurſe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Ah ﬁr, ah ﬁr. Wel death’s the end of all.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Spakeﬅ thou of Iuliet, how is it with her?
Doth ſhe not thinke me an olde murderer,
Now I haue ﬅainde the childhood of her ioy,
With bloud remou’d but little from her owne?
Where is ſhe? and how doth ſhe? And whay ſayes
My conceal’d Lady to our canceld loue?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Oh ſhe ſaith nothing, but weepes and pules,
And now fals on her bed, now on the ground,
And Tybalt cryes, and then on Romeo calles.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: As if that name ſhot from the deadly leuel of a gun
Did murder her, as that names curſed hand
Murderd her kinſman. Ah tell me holy Fryer
In what vile part of this Anatomy
Doth my name lye? Tell me that I may ſacke
The hatefull manﬁon?

scene.stagedir: He offers to ﬅab himſelfe, and Nurſe ſnatches the dagger away.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Ah?

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Hold, ﬅay thy hand: art thou a man? thy forme
Cryes out thou art, but thy wilde aƈes denote
The vnreſonable furyes of a beaﬅ.
Vnſeemely woman in a ſeeming man,
Or ill beſeeming beaﬅ in ſeeming both.
Thou haﬅ amaz’d me. By my holy order,
I thought thy diſpoﬁtion better temperd,
Haﬅ thou ﬂaine Tybalt? wilt thou ﬂay thy ſelfe?
And ﬂay thy Lady too, that liues in thee?
Rouſe vp thy ſpirits, thy Lady Iuliet liues,
For whoſe ſweet ſake thou wert but lately dead:
There are thou happy. Tybalt would kill thee,
But thou ﬂlueﬅ Tybalt, there art thou happy too.
A packe of bleﬃngs lights vpon thy backe,
Happines Courts thee in his beﬅ array:
But like a misbehaude and ſullen wench
Thou frownﬅ vpon thy Fate that ſmilles on thee.
Take heede, take heede, for ſuch dye miſerable.
Goe get thee to thy loue as was decreed:
Aſcend her Chamber Window, hence and comfort her,
But looke thou ﬅay not till the watch be ſet:
For then thou canﬅ not paﬀe to Mantua.
Nurſe prouide all things in a readines,
Comfort thy Miﬅreﬀe, haﬅe the houſe to bed,
Which heauy ſorrow makes them apt vnto.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Good Lord what a thing learning is,
I could haue ﬅayde heere all this night
To heare good counſell. Well Sir,
Ile tell my Lady that you will come.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Doe ſo and bidde my ſweet prepare to childe,
Farwell good Nurſe.

scene.stagedir: Nurſe offers to goe in and turnes againe.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Heere is a Ring Sir, that ſhe bad me giue you,

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: How well my comfort is reuiud by this.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Soiorne in Mantua, Ile finde out your man,
And he ſhall ﬁgnifie from time to time:
Euery good hap that doth befall thee heere.
Farwell.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: But that a ioy, paﬅ ioy cryes out on me,
It were a griefe ſo breefe to part with thee:

scene.stagedir: Enter olde Capolet and his Wife, with County Paris.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Thinges haue fallen out Sir ſo vnluckily,
That we haue had no time to moue my daughter.
Looke yee Sir, ſhe lou’d her kinſman dearely,
And ſo did I. Well, we were borne to dye,
Wife wher’s your daughter, is ſhe in her chamber?
I thinke ſhe meanes not to come downe to night.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Theſe times of woe affoord no time to wooe,
Maddam farwell, commend me to your daughter.

scene.stagedir: Paris offers to goe in, and Capolet calles him againe.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Sir Paris? Ile make a deſperate tender of my child.
I thinke ſhe will be rulde in all reſpeƈtes by mee:
But ſoft what day is this?

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Munday my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Oh then Wenſday is too ſoone,
On Thurſday let it be: you ſhall be maried.
Wee’le make no great a doe, a frend or two, or ſo:
For looke ye Sir, Tybalt being ﬂaine ſo lately,
It will be thought we held him careleﬂye:
If we ſhould reuell much, therefore we will haue
Some halfe a dozen frends and make no more adoe.
But what ſay you to Thurſday.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: My Lorde I wiſhe that Thurſday were to morrow.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Wife goe you to your daughter, ere you goe to bed.
Acquaint her with the County Paris loue,
Fare well my Lord till Thurſday next.
Wife gette you to your daughter, Light to my Chamber.
Afore me it is ſo very very late,
That we may call it earely by and by.

scene.stagedir: Enter Romeo and Iuliet at the window.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet nere day,
It was the Nightingale and not the Larke
That pierﬅ the fearfull hollow of thine eare:
Nightly ſhe ﬁngs on yon Pomegranate tree,
Beleeue me loue, it was the Nightingale.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: It was the Larke the Herald of the Morne,
And not the Nightingale. See Loue what enuious ﬅrakes
Doo lace the ſeuering clowdes in yonder Eaﬅ.
Nights candles are burnt out, and iocond Day
Stands tiptoes on the myﬅie mountaine tops.
I muﬅ be gone and liue, or ﬅay and dye.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: Yon light is not day light, I know it I:
It is ſome Meteor that the Sunne exhales,
To be this night to thee a Torch-bearer,
And light thee on thy way to Mantua.
Then ﬅay awhile, thou ſhalt not goe ſoone.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Let me ﬅay here, let me be tane, and dye:
If thou wilt haue it ſo, I am content.
Ile ſay yon gray is not the Mornings Eye,
It is the pale reflex of Cynthias brow.
Ile ſay it is the Nightingale that beares
The vaultie heauen ſo high aboue our heads,
And not the Larke the Meﬀenger of Morne.
Come death and welcome, Iuliet wils it ſo.
What ſayes my Loue? lets talke, tis not yet day.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: It is, it is, be gone, flye hence away.
It is the Larke that ﬁngs ſo out of tune,
Straining harſh Diſcords and vnpleaﬁng Sharpes.
Some ſay, the Larke makes ſweete Diuiﬁon:
This doth not ſo: for this diuideth vs.
Some ſay the Larke and loathed Toad change eyes,
I would that now they had changd voyces too:
Since arme from arme her voyce doth vs affray,
Hunting thee hence with Huntſvp to the day.
So now be gone, more light and light it growes.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: More light and light, more darke and darke our woes.
Farewell my Loue, one kiﬀe and Ile deſcend.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: Are thou gone ſo, my Lord, my Loue, my Frend?
I muﬅ heare from thee euerie day in the hower:
For in an hower there are manie minutes,
Minutes are dayes, ſo will I number them:
Oh, by this count I ſhall be much in yeares,
Ere I ſee thee againe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Farewell, I will omit no opportunitie
That may conueigh my greetings loue to thee.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Oh, thinkﬅ thou we ſhall euer meete againe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: No doubt, no doubt, and all this woe ſhall ſerue
For ſweete diſcourſes in the time to come.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: Oh God, I haue an ill diuining ſoule.
Me thinkes I ſee thee now thou art below
Like one dead in the bottome of a Tombe:
Either mine ey-ﬁght failes, or thou lookﬅ pale.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: And truﬅ me Loue, in my eye ſo doo you,
Drie ſorrow drinkes our blood: adieu, adieu.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Madame beware, take heed the day is broke,
Your Mother’s comming to your Chamber, make all ſure.

scene.stagedir: She goeth downe from the window.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Where are you Daughter?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: What Ladie, Lambe, what Iuliet?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: How now, who calls?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: It is your Mother.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Why how now Juliet?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Madam, I am not well.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: What euermore weeping for your Coſens death:
I thinke thoult waſh him from his graue with teares.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I cannot chuſe, hauing ſo great a loﬀe.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: I cannot blame thee.
But it greeues thee more that Villaine liues.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: What Villaine, Madame?

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: That Villaine Romeo.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Villaine and he are manie miles a ſunder.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Content thee Girle, if I could finde a man
I ſoone would ſend to Mantua where he is,
That ſhould beﬅow on him ſo ſure a draught,
