As he ſhould ſoone beare Tybalt companie.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Finde you the meanes, and Ile finde ſuch a man:
For whileﬅ he liues, my heart ſhall nere be light
Till I behold him, dead is my poore heart.
Thus for a Kinſman vext?

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Well let that paﬀe. I come to bring thee ioyfull newes.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: And ioy comes well in ſuch a needfull time.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Well then, thou haﬅ a carefull Father Girle,
And one who pittying thy needfull ﬅate,
Hath found thee out a happie day of ioy.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: What day is that I pray you?

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Marry my Childe,
The gallant, yong and youthfull Gentleman,
The Countie Paris at Saint Peters Church,
Early next Thurſday morning muﬅ prouide,
To make you there a glad and ioyfull Bride.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Now by Saint Peters Church and Peter too,
He ſhall not there make mee a ioyfull Bride.
Are theſe the newes you had to tell me of?
Marrie here are newes indeed. Madame I will not marrie yet.
And when I doo, it ſhalbe rather Romeo whom I hate,
Than Countie Paris than I cannot loue.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Here comes your Father, you may tell him ſo.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Why how now, euermore ſhowring?
In one little bodie thou reſembleﬅ a ſea, a barke, a ﬅorme:
For this thy bodie which I tearme a barke,
Still floating in thy euerfalling teares,
And toﬅ with ﬁghes ariﬁng from thy hart:
Will without ſuccour ſhip wracke preſently.
But heare you Wife, what haue you ſounded her, what ſaies ſhe to it?

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: I haue, but ſhe will none ſhe thankes ye:
VVould God that ſhe were married to her graue.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: What will ſhe not, doth ſhe not thanke vs, doth ſhe not wexe proud?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Not proud ye haue, but thankfull that ye haue:
Proud can I neuer be of that I hate,
But thankfull euen for hate that is ment loue.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Proud and I thanke you, and I thanke you not,
And yet not proud. VVhats here, chop logicke.
Proud me no prouds, nor thanke me no thankes,
But ſettle your fine ioynts on Thurſday next
To goe with Paris to Saint Peters Church,
Or I will drag you on a hurdle thether.
Out you greene ﬁcknes baggage, out you tallow face.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: Good father heare me ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: I tell thee what, eyther reſoulue on thurſday next
To goe with Paris to Saint Peters Church:
Or henceforth neuer looke me in the face.
Speake not, reply not, for my fingers ytch.
Why wife, we thought that we were ſcarcely bleﬅ
That God had ſent vs but this onely chyld:
But now I ſee this one is one too much,
And that we haue a croﬀe in hauing her.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Mary God in heauen bleﬀe her my Lord,
You are too blame to rate her ſo.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: And why my Lady wiſedome? hold your tung,
Good prudence ſmatter with your goﬃps, goe.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Why my Lord I ſpeake no treaſon.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Oh goddegodden.
Vtter your grauity ouer a goﬃps boule,
For heere we need it not.

speech.speaker: Mo:
speech.line: My Lord ye are too hotte.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Gods bleﬀed mother wife it mads me,
Day, night, early, late, at home, abroad,
Alone, in company, waking or ﬂeeping,
Still my care hath beene to ſee her matcht.
And hauing now found out a Gentleman,
Of Princely parentage, youthfull, and nobly trainde.
Stuft as they ſay with honorable parts,
Proportioned as ones heart coulde wiſh a man:
And then to haue a wretched whyning foole,
A puling mammet in her fortunes tender,
To ſay I cannot loue, I am too young, I pray you pardon mee?
But if you cannot wedde Ile pardon you.
Graze where you will, you ſhall not houſe with me.
Looke to it, thinke ont, I doe not vſe to ieﬅ.
I tell yee what, Thurſday is neere,
Lay hand on heart, aduiſe, bethinke your ſelfe,
If you be mine, Ile giue you to my frend:
If not, hang, drowne, ﬅarue, beg,
Dye in the ﬅreetes: for by my Soule
Ile neuer more acknowledge thee,
Nor what I haue ſhall euer doe thee good,
Thinke ont, looke toot, I doe not vſe to ieﬅ.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Is there no pitty hanging in the cloudes,
That lookes into the bottom of my woes?
I doe beſeech you Madame, caﬅ me not away,
Defer this mariage for a day or two,
Or if you cannot, make my mariage bed
In that dimme monument where Tybalt lyes.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Nay be aﬀured I will not ſpeake a word.
Do what thou wilt for I haue done with thee.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Ah Nurſe what comfort? what counſell canﬅ thou giue me.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Now truﬅ me Madame, I know not what to ſay:
Your Romeo he is baniſht, and all the world to nothing
He neuer dares returne to challendge you.
Now I thinke good you marry with this County,
Oh he is a gallant Gentleman, Romeo is but a diſhclout
In reſpeƈt of him. I promiſe you
I thinke you happy in this ſecond match.
As for your husband he is dead:
Or twere as good he were, for you haue no vſe of him.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Speakﬅ thou this from thy heart?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: I and from my ſoule, or els beſhrew them both.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: What ſay you Madame?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Well, thou haﬅ comforted me wondrous much,
I pray thee goe thy waies vnto my mother
Tell her I am gone hauing diſpleaſde my Father
To Fryer Laurence Cell to confeﬀe me,
And to be abſolu’d.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: I will, and this is wiſely done.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Auncient damnation, O moﬅ curſed fiend.
Is it more ﬁnne to wiſh me thus forſworne,
Or to diſpraiſe him with the ſelfe ſame tongue
That thou haﬅ praiſde him with aboue compare
So many thouſand times? Goe Counſellor,
Thou and my boſom henceforth ſhal be twaine.
Ile to the Fryer to know his remedy,
If all faile els, I haue the power to dye.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: On Thurſday ſay ye: the time is very ſhort,

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: My Father Capolet will haue it ſo,
And I am nothing ﬂacke to ﬂow his haﬅ.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: You ſay you doe not know the Ladies minde?
Vneuen is the courſe, I like it not.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Immoderately ſhe weepes for Tybalts death,
And therefore haue I little talkt of loue.
For Venus ſmiles not in a houſe of teares,
Now Sir, her father thinkes it daungerous:
That ſhe doth giue her ſorrow ſo much ſway.
And in his wiſedome haﬅs our mariage,
To ﬅop the inundation of her teares.
Which too much minded by her ſelfe alone
May be put from her by ſocietie.
Now doe ye know the reaſon of this haﬅ.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: I would I knew not why it ſhould be ﬂowd.
Heere comes the Lady to my cell,

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Welcome my loue, my Lady and my wife:

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: That may be ﬁr, when I may be a wife,

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: That may be, muﬅ be loue, on thurſday next.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: What muﬅ be ſhalbe.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Thats a certaine text.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: What come ye to confeﬃon to this Fryer?

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: To tell you that were to confeﬀe to you.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Do not deny to him that you loue me.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I will confeﬀe to you that I loue him,

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: So I am ſure you will that you loue me.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: And if I doe, it wilbe of more price,
Being ſpoke behinde your backe, than to your face.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Poore ſoule thy face is much abuſ’d with teares.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: The teares haue got ſmall viƈtory by that,
For it was bad enough before their ſpite.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Thou wrongﬅ it more than teares by that report.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: That is no wrong ﬁr, that is a truth:
And what I ſpake I ſpake it to my face.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Thy face is mine and thou haﬅ ﬂaundred it.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: It may be ſo, for it is not mine owne.
Are you at leaſure holy Father now:
Or ſhall I come to you at euening Maﬀe?

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: My leaſure ſerues me penﬁue daughter now.
My Lord you muﬅ entreate the time alone.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: God ſheild I ſhould diﬅurbe deuotion,
Iuliet farwell, and keepe this holy kiﬀe.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: Goe ſhut the doore and when thou haﬅ done ſo,
Come weepe with me that am paﬅ cure, paﬅ help,

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Ah Iuliet, I already know thy griefe,
I heare thou muﬅ and nothiug may proroge it,
On Thurſday next be married to the Countie.

speech.speaker: Iu:
speech.line: Tell me not Frier that thou hearﬅ of it,
Vnleﬀe thou tell me how we may preuent it.
Giue me ſome ſudden counſell: els behold
Twixt my extreames and me, this bloodie Knife
Shall play the Vmpeere, arbitrating that
Which the Commiſsion of thy yeares and arte
Could to no iﬀue of true honour bring.
Speake not, be briefe: for I deﬁre to die,
If what thou ſpeakﬅ, ſpeake not of remedie.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Stay Juliet, I doo ſpie a kinde of hope,
VVhich craues as deſperate an execution,
As that is deſperate we would preuent.
If rather than to marrie Countie Paris
Thou haﬅ the ﬅrength or will to ﬂay thy ſelfe,
Tis not vnlike that thou wilt vndertake
A thing like death to chyde away this ſhame,
That coapﬅ with death it ſelfe to flye from blame.
And if thou dooﬅ, Ile giue thee remedie.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: Oh bid me leape (rather than marrie Paris)
From off the battlements of yonder tower:
Or chaine me to ſome ﬅeeple mountaines top,
VVhere roaring Beares and ſauage Lions are:
Or ſhut me nightly in a Charnell-houſe,
VVith reekie ſhankes, and yeolow chaples ſculls:
Or lay me in tombe with one new dead:
Things that to heare them namde haue made me tremble;
And I will doo it without feare or doubt,
To keep my ſelfe a faithfull vnﬅaind VVife
To my deere Lord, my deereﬅ Romeo.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Hold Iuliet, hie thee home, get thee to bed,
Let not thy Nurſe lye with thee in thy Chamber:
And when thou art alone, take thou this Violl,
And this diﬅilled Liquor drinke thou off:
VVhen preſently through all thy veynes ſhall run
A dull and heauie ﬂumber, which ſhall ſeaze
Each yitall ſpirit: for no Pulſe ſhall keepe
His naturall progreﬀe, but ſurceaſe to beate:
No ﬁgne of breath ſhall teﬅifie thou liuﬅ.
And in this borrowed likenes of ſhrunke death,
Thou ſhalt remaine full two and fortie houres.
And when thou art laid in thy Kindreds Vault,
Ile ſend in haﬅ to Mantua to thy Lord.
And he ſhall come and take thee from thy graue.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Frier I goe, be ſure thou ſend for my deare Romeo.

scene.stagedir: Enter olde Capolet, his Wife, Nurſe, and Seruingman.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Where are you ﬁrra?

speech.speaker: Sor:
speech.line: Heere forſooth.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Goe, prouide me twentie cunning Cookes.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: I warrant you Sir, let me alone for that, Ile knowe them by licking their fingers.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: How canﬅ thou know them ſo?

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Ah Sir, tis an ill Cooke cannot licke his owne fingers.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Well get you gone.
But wheres this Head-ﬅrong?

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Shees gone (my Lord) to Frier Laurence Cell
To be confeﬅ.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Ah, he may hap to doo ſome good of her,
A headﬅrong ſelfewild harlotrie it is.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: See here ſhe commeth from Confeſsion,

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: How now my Head-ﬅrong, where haue you bin gadding?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Where I haue learned to repent the ﬁn
Of froward wilfull oppoﬁtion
Gainﬅ you and your beheﬅs, and am enioynd
By holy Laurence to fall proﬅrate here,
And craue remiſsion of ſo foule a faƈt.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Why thats well ſaid.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Now before God this holy reuerent Frier
All our whole Citie is much bound vnto.
Goe tell the Countie preſently of this,
For I will haue this knot knit vp to morrow.

speech.speaker: Jul:
speech.line: Nurſe, will you go with me to my Cloſet,
To ſort ſuch things as ſhall be requiﬁte
Againﬅ to morrow.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: I pree thee doo, good Nurſe goe in with her,
Helpe her to ſort Tyres, Rebatoes, Chaines,
And I will come vnto you preſently,

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Come ſweet hart, ſhall we goe

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I pree thee let vs.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Me thinks on Thurſday would be time enough.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: I ſay I will haue this diſpatcht to morrow,
Goe one and certefie the Count thereof.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: I pray my Lord, let it be Thurſday.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: I ſay to morrow while ſhees in the mood.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: We ſhall be ſhort in our prouiﬁon.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: Let me alone for that, goe get you in,
Now before God my heart is paſsing light,
To ſee her thus conformed to our will.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Come, come, what need you anie thing elſe?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Nothing good Nurſe, but leaue me to my ſelfe:
For I doo meane to lye alone to night.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Well theres a cleane ſmocke vnder your pillow, and ſo good night.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: What are you buﬁe, doo you need my helpe?

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: No Madame, I deﬁre to lye alone,
For I haue manie things to thinke vpon.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Well then good night, be ﬅirring Iuliet,
The Countie will be earlie here to morrow.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Farewell, God knowes when wee ſhall meete againe.
Ah, I doo take a fearfull thing in hand.
What if this Potion ſhould not worke at all,
Muﬅ I of force be married to the Countie?
This ſhall forbid it. Knife, lye thou there.
What if the Frier ſhould giue me this drinke
To poyſon mee, for feare I ſhould diſcloſe
Our former marriage? Ah, I wrong him much,
He is a holy and religious Man:
I will not entertaine ſo bad a thought.
What if I ſhould be ﬅifled in the Toomb?
Awake an houre before the appointed time:
Ah then I feare I ſhall be lunaticke,
And playing with my dead forefathers bones,
Daſh out my franticke braines. Me thinkes I ſee
My Coﬁn Tybalt weltring in his bloud,
Seeking for Romeo: ﬅay Tybalt, ﬅay.
Romeo I come, this doe I drinke to thee.

scene.stagedir: She fals vpon her bed within the Curtaines.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Thats well ſaid Nurſe, ſet all in redines,
The Countie will be heere immediatly.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Make haﬅ, make haﬅ, for it is almoﬅ day,
The Curfewe bell hath rung, t’is foure a clocke,
Looke to your bakt meates good Angelica.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Goe get you to bed you cotqueane. I faith you will be ﬁcke anone.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: I warrant thee Nurſe I haue ere now watcht all night, and haue taken no harme at all.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: I you haue beene a mouſe hunt in your time.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: A Ielous hood, a Ielous hood: How now ﬁrra?
What haue you there?

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Forſooth Logs.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Goe, goe chooſe dryer. Will will tell thee where thou ſhalt fetch them.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Nay I warrant let me alone, I haue a heade I troe to chooſe a Log.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Well goe thy way, thou ſhalt be logger head.
Come, come, make haﬅ call vp your daughter,
The Countie will be heere with muﬁcke ﬅraight.
Gods me hees come, Nurſe call vp my daughter.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Goe, get you gone. What lambe, what Lady birde? faﬅ I warrant. What Iuliet? well, let the County take you in your bed: yee ﬂeepe for a weeke now, but the next night, the Countie Paris hath ſet vp his reﬅ that you ſhal reﬅ but little. What lambe I ſay, faﬅ ﬅill: what Lady, Loue, whatbride, what Iuliet? Gods me how ſound ſhe ﬂeeps? Nay then I ſee I muﬅ wake you indeed. Whats heere, laide on your bed, dreﬅ in your cloathes and down, ah me, alack the day, ſome Aqua vitæ hoe.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: How now whats the matter?

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Alack the day, ſhees dead, ſhees dead, ſhees dead.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Accurﬅ, vnhappy, miſerable time.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Come, come, make haﬅ, wheres my daughter?

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: Ah ſhees dead, ſhees dead.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Stay, let me ſee, all pale and wan.
Accurſed time, vnfortunate olde man.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: What is the bride ready to goe to Church?

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Ready to goe, but neuer to returne.
O Sonne the night before thy wedding day,
Hath Death laine with thy bride, flower as ſhe is,
Deflowerd by him, ſee, where ſhe lyes,
Death is my Sonne in Law, to him I giue all that I haue.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Haue I though long to ſee this mornings face,
And doth it now preſent ſuch prodegies?
Accurﬅ, vnhappy, miſerable man,
Forlorne, forſaken, deﬅitute I am:
Borne to the world to be a ﬂaue in it.
Diﬅreﬅ, remediles, and vnfortunate.
O heauens, O nature, wherefore did you make me,
To liue ſo vile, ſo wretched as I ſhall.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: O heere ſhe lies that was our hope, our ioy,
And being dead, dead ſorrow nips vs all.

scene.stagedir: All at once cry out and wring their hand.

speech.speaker: All cry:
speech.line: And all our ioy, and all our hope is dead,
Dead, loﬅ, vndone, abſented, wholy fled.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Cruel, vniuﬅ, impartiall deﬅinies,
Why to this day haue you preſeru’d my life?
To ſee my hope, my ﬅay, my ioy, my life,
Depriude of ſence, of life, of all by death,
Cruell, vniuﬅ, impartiall deﬅinies.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: O ſad fac’d ſorrow map of miſery,
Why this ſad time haue I deﬁrd to ſee.
This day, this vniuﬅ, this impartiall day
Wherein I hop’d to ſee my comfort full,
To be depriude by ſuddaine deﬅinie.

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: O woe, alacke, diﬅreﬅ, why ſhould I liue?
To ſee this day, this miſerable day.
Alacke the time that euer I was borne,
To be partaker of this deﬅinie.
Alacke the day, alacke and welladay.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: O peace for ſhame, if not for charity.
Your daughter liues in peace and happines,
And it is vaine to wiſh it otherwiſe.
Come ﬅicke your Roſemary in this dead coarſe,
And as the cuﬅome of our Country is,
In all her beﬅ and ſumptous ornaments,
Conuay her where her Anceﬅors lie tomb’d,

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Let it be ſo, come wofull ſorrow mates,
Let vs together taﬅe this bitter fate.

scene.stagedir: They all but the Nurſe goe foorth, caﬅing Roſemary on her and ſhutting the Curtens.

speech.speaker: Nur:
speech.line: Put vp, put vp, this is a wofull caſe.
I by my troth Miﬅreﬀe is it, it had need be mended.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Alack alack what ſhal I doe, come Fidlers play me ſome mery dumpe.
A ﬁr, this is no time to play.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: You will not then?
No marry will wee.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Then will I giue it you, and ſoundly to.
What will you giue vs?

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: The fidler, Ile re you, Ile fa you, Ile fol you.
If you re vs and fa vs, we will note you.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: I will put vp my Iron dagger, and beate you with my wodden wit. Come on Simon found Pot, Ile poſe you,
Lets heare.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: When griping griefe the heart doth wound,
And dolefull dumps the minde oppreﬀe:
Then muﬁque with her ﬁluer ſound,
Why ﬁluer ſound? Why ﬁluer ſound?
I thinke becauſe muﬁcke hath a ſweet ſound.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Pretie, what ſay you Mathew minikine?
I thinke becauſe Muﬁtions ſound for ﬁluer.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: Prettie too: come, what ſay you?
I ſay nothing.

speech.speaker: Ser:
speech.line: I thinke ſo, Ile ſpeake for you becauſe you are the Singer. I ſaye Siluer ſound, becauſe ſuch Fellowes as you haue ﬁldome Golde for ſounding. Farewell Fidlers, farewell.
Farewell and be hangd: come lets goe.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: If I may trﬅ the flattering Eye of Sleepe,
My Dreame preſagde ſome good euent to come.
My boſome Lord ﬁts chearfull in his throne,
And I am comforted with pleaﬁng dreames.
Me thought I was this night alreadie dead:
(Strange dreames that giue a dead man leaue to thinke)
And that my Ladie Iuliet came to me,
And breathd ſuch life with kiﬀes in my lips,
That I reuiude and was an Emperour.
Newes from Verona. How now Balthaſar,
How doth my Ladie? Is my Father well?
How fares my Juliet? that I aske againe:
If ſhe be well, then nothing can be ill.

speech.speaker: Balt:
speech.line: Then nothing can be ill, for ſhe is well,
Her bodie ﬂeepes in Capels Monument,
And her immortall parts with Angels dwell.
Pardon me Sir, that am the Meﬀenger of ſuch bad tidings.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Is it euen ſo? then I defie my Starres.
Goe get me incke and paper, hyre poﬅ horſe,
I will not ﬅay in Mantua to night.

speech.speaker: Balt:
speech.line: Pardon me Sir, I will not leaue you thus,
Your lookes are dangerous and full of feare:
I dare not, nor I will not leaue you yet.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Doo as I bid thee, get me incke and paper,
And hyre thoſe horſe: ﬅay not I ſay.
Well Iuliet, I will lye with thee to night.
Lets ſee for meanes. As I doo remember
Here dwells a Pothecarie whom oft I noted
As I paﬅ by, whoſe needie ſhop is ﬅufft
With beggerly accounts of emptie boxes:
And in the ſame Aligarta hangs,
Olde endes of packthred, and cakes of Roſes,
Are thinly ﬅrewed to make vp a ſhow.
Him as I noted, thus with my ſelfe I thought:
And if a man ſhould need a poyſon now,
(Whoſe preſent ſale is death in Mantua)
Here he might buy it. This thought of mine
Did but forerunne my need: and here about he dwels.
Being Holiday the Beggers ſhop is ſhut.
What ho Apothecarie, come forth I ſay.

speech.speaker: Apo:
speech.line: VVho calls, what would you ﬁr?

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Heeres twentie duckates,
Giue me a dram of ſome ſuch ſpeeding geere,
As will diſpatch the wearie takers life,
As ſuddenly as powder being fierd
From forth a Cannons mouth.

speech.speaker: Apo:
speech.line: Such drugs I haue I muﬅ of force confeﬀe,
But yet the law is death to thoſe that ſell them.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Art thou ſo bare and full of pouertie,
And dooﬅ thou feare to violate the Law?
The Law is not thy frend, not the Lawes frend,
And therefore make no conſcience of the law:
Vpon thy backe hangs ragged Miſerie,
And ﬅarued Famine dwelleth in thy cheekes.

speech.speaker: Apo:
speech.line: My pouertie but not my will conſents.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I pay thy pouertie, but not thy will.

speech.speaker: Apo:
speech.line: Hold take you this, and put it in anie liquid thing you will, and it will ſerue had you the liues of twenty men.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Hold, take this gold, worſe poyſon to mens ſoules
Than this which thou haﬅ giuen me. Goe hye thee hence,
Goe buy the cloathes, and get thee into fleſh.
Come cordiall and not poyſon, goe with mee
To Iuliets Graue: for there muﬅ I vſe thee.

speech.speaker: John.
speech.line: VVhat Frier Laurence, Brother, ho?

speech.speaker: Laur:
speech.line: This ſame ſhould be the voyce of Frier Iohn.
VVhat newes from Mantua, what will Romeo come?

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Going to ſeeke a barefoote Brother out,
One of our order to aﬀociate mee,
Here in this Cittie viﬁting the ﬁck,
VVhereas the infeƈtious peﬅilence remaind:
And being by the Searchers of the Towne
Found and examinde, we were both ſhut vp.

speech.speaker: Laur:
speech.line: VVho bare my letters then to Romeo?

speech.speaker: Iohn:
speech.line: I haue them ﬅill, and here they are.

speech.speaker: Laur:
speech.line: Now by my holy Order,
The letters were not nice, but of great weight.
Goe get thee hence, and get me preſently
A ſpade and mattocke.

speech.speaker: Iohn:
speech.line: Well I will preſently go fetch thee them.

speech.speaker: Laur:
speech.line: Now muﬅ I to the Monument alone,
Leaﬅ that the Ladie ſhould before I come
Be wakde from ﬂeepe. I will hye
To free her from that Tombe of miſerie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Countie Paris and his Page with flowers and ſweete water.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Put out the torch, and lye thee all along
Vnder this Ew-tree, keeping thine eare cloſe to the hollow ground.
And if thou heare one tread within this Churchyard,
Staight giue me notice.

speech.speaker: Boy:
speech.line: I will my Lord.

scene.stagedir: Paris ﬅrewes the Tomb with flowers.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Sweete Flower, with flowers I ﬅrew thy Bridale bed:
Sweete Tombe that in thy circuite doﬅ containe,
The perfeƈt modell of eternitie:
Faire Iuliet that with Angells doﬅ remaine,
Accept this lateﬅ fauour at my hands,
That liuing honourd thee, and being dead
With funerall praiſes doo adorne thy Tombe.
My Lord.

scene.stagedir: Enter Romeo and Balthaſar, with a torch, a a mattocke, and a crow of yron.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: The boy giues warning, ſomething doth approach.
What curſed foote wanders this was to night,
To ﬅay my obſequies and true loues rites?
What with a torch, muffle me night a while.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Giue mee this mattocke, and this wrentching Iron
And take theſe letters, early in the morning,
See thou deliuer them to my Lord and Father.
So get thee gone and trouble me no more.
Why I deſcend into this bed of death,
Is partly to behold my Ladies face,
But chiefly to take from her dead finger,
A precious ring which I muﬅ vſe
In deare imployment but if thou wilt ﬅay,
Further to prie in what I vndertake,
By heauen Ile teare thee ioynt by ioynt,
And ﬅrewe thys hungry churchyard with thy lims.
The time and my intents are ſauage, wilde.

speech.speaker: Balt:
speech.line: Well, Ile be gone and not trouble you.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: So ſhalt thou win my fauour, take thou this,
Commend me to my Father, farwell good fellow.

speech.speaker: Balt:
speech.line: Yet for all this will I not part from hence.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Thou deteﬅable maw, thou womb of death,
Gorde with the deareﬅ morſell of the earth.
Thus I enforce thy rotten iawes to ope.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: This is that baniſht haughtie Mountague,
That murderd my louescoſen, I will apprehend him.
Stop thy vnhallowed toyle vile Mountague.
Can vengeance be purſued further then death?
I doe attach thee as a fellon heere.
The Law condemnes thee, therefore thou muﬅ dye.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: I muﬅ indeed, and therefore came I hither,
Good youth begone, tempt not a deſperate man.
Heape not another ﬁnne vpon my head
By ſheding of thy bloud, I doe proteﬅ
I loue thee better then I loue my ſelfe:
For I come hyther armde againﬅ my ſelfe,

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: I doe defie thy coniurations:
And doe attach thee as a fellon heere.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: What doﬅ thou tempt me, then haue at thee boy.

speech.speaker: Boy:
speech.line: O Lord they fight, I will goe call the watch.

speech.speaker: Par:
speech.line: Ah I am ﬂaine, if thou be mercifull
Open the tombe, lay me with Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Rom:
speech.line: Yfaith I will, let me peruſe this face,
Mercutios kinſman, noble County Paris?
What ſaid my man, when my betoﬀed ſoule
Did not regard him as we paﬅ a long.
Did he not ſay Paris ſhould haue maried
Iuliet? eyther he Œaid ſo, or I dreamd it ſo.
But I will ſatisfie thy laﬅ requeﬅ,
For thou haﬅ prizd thy loue aboue thy life.
Death lye thou there, by a dead man interd,
How oft haue many at the houre of death
Beene blith and pleaſant? which their keepers call
A lightning before death But how may I
Call this a lightning. Ah deare Iuliet,
How well thy beauty doth become this graue?
O I beleeue that vnſubﬅanciall death,
Is amorous, and doth court my loue.
Therefore will I, O heere, O euer heere,
Set vp my euerlaﬅing reﬅ
With wormes, that are thy chambermayds.
Come deſperate Pilot now at once runne on
The daſhing rockes thy ſea-ﬁcke weary barge.
Heers to my loue. O true Apothecary:
Thy drugs are ſwift: thus with a kiﬀe I dye.
How oft to night haue theſe my aged feete
Stumbled at graues as I did paﬀe along.
Whoſe there?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: A frend and one that knowes you well.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Who is it that conſorts ſo late the dead,
What light is yon? if I be not deceiued,
Me thinkes it burnes in Capels monument?

speech.speaker: Man
speech.line: It doth ſo holy Sir, and there is one
That loues you dearely.

speech.speaker: Fr.
speech.line: Who is it?

speech.speaker: Man:
speech.line: Romeo.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: How long hath he beene there?

speech.speaker: Man:
speech.line: Full halfe an houre and more.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Goe with me thether.

speech.speaker: Man:
speech.line: I dare not ﬁr, he knowes not I am heere:
On paine of death he chargde me to be gone,
And not for to diﬅurbe him in his enterprize.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Then muﬅ I goe: my minde preſageth ill.
speech.stagedir: Fryer ﬅoops and lookes on the blood and weapons.
speech.line: What bloud is this that ﬅaines the entrance
Of this marble ﬅony monument?
What meanes theſe maiﬅerles and goory weapons?
Ah me I doubt, whoſe heere? what Romeo dead?
Who and Paris too? what vnluckie houre
Is acceﬀary to ſo foule a ﬁnne?
The Lady ﬅurres.
Ah comfortable Fryer.
I doe remember well where I ſhould be,
And what we talkt of: but yet I cannot ſee
Him for whoſe ſake I vndertooke this hazard.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: Lady come foorth I heare ſome noiſe at hand,
We ſhall be taken, Paris he is ﬂaine,
And Romeo dead: and if we heere be tane
We ſhall be thought to be as acceﬀarie.
I will prouide for you in ſome cloſe Nunery.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Ah leaue me leaue me, I will not from hence.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: I heare ſome noiſe, I dare not ﬅay, come, come.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: Goe get thee gone.
Whats heere a cup cloſde in my louers hands?
Ah churle drinke all, and leaue no drop for me.

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: This way, this way.

speech.speaker: Iul:
speech.line: I, noiſe? then muﬅ I be reſolute.
O happy dagger thou ſhalt end my feare,
Reﬅ in my boſome, thus I come to thee.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Come looke about, what weapons haue we heere?
See frends where Iuliet two daies buried,
New bleeding wounded, ſearch and ſee who’s neare.
Attach and bring them to vs preſently.
Captaine heers a Fryer with tooles about him,
Fitte to ope a tombe.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: A great ſuſpition keep him ſafe.
Heeres Romeos Man.

speech.speaker: Capt:
speech.line: Keepe him to be examinde.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: What early miſchiefe call, vs vp ſo ſoone.

speech.speaker: Capt:
speech.line: O noble Prince, ſee here
Where Juliet that hath lyen intoombd two dayes,
Warme and freſh bleeding, Romeo and Countie Paris
Likewiſe newly ﬂaine.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: Search ſeeke about to finde the murderers.

scene.stagedir: Enter olde Capolet and his Wife.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: What rumor’s this that is ſo early vp?

speech.speaker: Moth:
speech.line: The people in the ﬅreetes crie Romeo,
And ſome on Iuliet: as if they alone
Had been the cauſe of ſuch a mutinie.

speech.speaker: Capo:
speech.line: See Wife, this dagger hath miﬅooke:
For (loe) the backe is emptie of yong Mountague,
And it is ſheathed in our Daughters breaﬅ.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: Come Mountague, for thou art early vp,
To ſee thy Sonne and Heire more early downe.

speech.speaker: Mount:
speech.line: Dread Souereigne, my Wife is dead to night,
And yong Benuolio is deceaſed too:
What further miſchiefe can there yet be found?

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: Firﬅ come and ſee, then ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Mount:
speech.line: O thou vntaught, what manners in is this
To preﬀe before thy Father to a graue.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: Come ſeale your mouthes of outrage for a while,
And let vs ſeeke to finde the Authors out
Of ſuch a hainous and ſeld ſeene miſchaunce.
Bring forth the parties in ſuſpition.

speech.speaker: Fr:
speech.line: I am the greateﬅ able to doo leaﬅ.
Moﬅ worthie Prince, heare me but ſpeake the truth.
And Ile informe you how theſe things fell out.
Juliet here ﬂaine was married to that Romeo,
Without her Fathers or her Mothers grant:
The Nurſe was priuie to the marriage.
The balefull day of this vnhappie marriage,
VVas Tybalts doomeſday: for which Romeo
VVas baniſhed from hence to Mantua.
He gone, her Father ſought by foule conﬅraint
To marrie her to Paris: But her Soule
(Loathing a ſecond Contraƈt) did refuſe
To giue conſent; and therefore did ſhe vrge me
Either to finde a meanes ſhe might auoyd
VVhat ſo her Father ſought to force her too:
Or els all deſperately ſhe threatned
Euen in my preſence to diſpatch her ſelfe.
Then did I giue her, (tutord by mine arte)
A potion that ſhould make her ſeeme as dead:
And told her that I would with all poﬅ ſpeed
Send hence to Mantua for her Romeo,
That he might come and take her from the Toombe.
But he that had my Letters (Frier John)
Seeking a Brother to aﬀociate him,
VVhereas the ﬁcke infeƈtion remaind,
VVas ﬅayed by the Searchers of the Towne,
But Romeo vnderﬅanding by his man,
That Iuliet was deceaſde, returnde in poﬅ
Vnto Verona for to ſee his loue.
VVhat after happened touching Paris death,
Or Romeos is to me vnknowne at all.
But when I came to take the Lady hence,
I found them dead, and ſhe awakt from ﬂeep:
VVhom faine I would haue taken from the tombe,
VVhich ſhe refuſed ſeeing Romeo dead.
Anone I heard the watch and then I fled,
VVhat afterhappened I am ignorant of.
And if in this ought haue miſcaried
By me, or by my meanes let my old life
Be ſacrificd ſome houre before his time.
To the moﬅ ﬅrickeﬅ rigor of the Law.

speech.speaker: Pry:
speech.line: VVe ﬅill haue knowne thee for a holy man,
VVheres Romeos man, what can he ſay in this?

speech.speaker: Balth:
speech.line: I brought my maiﬅer word that ſhee was dead,
And then he poaﬅed ﬅraight from Mantua,
Vnto this Toombe. Theſe Letters he deliuered me,
Charging me early giue them to his Father.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: Lets ſee the Letters, I will read them ouer.
VVhere is the Counties Boy that calld the VVatch?

speech.speaker: Boy:
speech.line: I brought my Maﬅer vnto Juliets graue,
But one approaching, ﬅraight I calld my Maﬅer.
At laﬅ they fought, I ran to call the VVatch.
And this is all that I can ſay or know.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: Theſ letters doe make good the Fryers wordes,
Come Capolet, and come olde Mountagewe.
VVhere are theſe enemies? ſee what hate hath done.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Come brother Mountague, giue me thy hand,
There is my daughters dowry: for now no more
Can I beﬅowe on her, thats all I haue.

speech.speaker: Moun:
speech.line: But I will giue them more, I will ereƈt
Her ﬅatue of pure golde:
That while Verona by that name is knowne.
There ſhall no ﬅatue of ſuch price be ſet,
As that of Romeos loued Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: As rich ſhall Romeo by his Lady lie,
Poore Sacrifices to our Enmitie.

speech.speaker: Prin:
speech.line: A gloomie peace this day doth with it bring.
Come, let vs hence,
To haue more talke of theſe ſad things.
Some ſhall be pardoned and ſome puniſhed:
For nere was heard a Storie of more woe,
Than this of Iuliet and her Romeo.
